NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
852 PM EDT THU AUG 18 2005

.DISCUSSION...CONVECTION THIS EVENING HAS SHOWN EARLY SIGNS OF 
WEAKENING AS WELL AS DIMINISHING IN COVERAGE.  LINGERING SCATTERED 
TSRA CONTINUE TO MOVE EAST AT 20 MPH ACROSS MAINLY THE NRN HALF OF E 
TN.  ONCE THIS ACTIVITY HAS PASSED...WILL UPDATE THE ZFPMRX...GRIDS 
AND WEB PRODUCTS.  SHOULD BE ABLE TO LOWER RAIN CHANCES TO 20% OR SO
...AND REMOVE MENTION OF THUNDER OVERNIGHT.  WILL PROBABLY ALSO ADD 
AREAS OF FOG...WHICH SHOULD DEVELOP IN MANY AREAS ONCE THE 
CONVECTIVE DEBRIS CLOUDINESS THINS OUT. 

&&

NC......NONE.

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 181830
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
230 PM EDT THU AUG 18 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND FRIDAY)...MODELS AND ENSEMBLES GENERALLY 
AGREE THAT ZONAL FLOW WILL AMPLIFY OVER THE PERIOD AS UPPER RIDGE 
BUILDS OVER THE CENTRAL GULF COAST REGION. THIS SHOULD PUSH THE WEAK 
FRONTAL BOUNDARY CURRENTLY DRAPED ACROSS THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS 
TO THE NORTH BY LATE IN THE FIRST PERIOD. ANTICIPATE RETURN TO MORE 
SCATTERED/DIURNAL CONVECTION AS BOUNDARY EXITS THE AREA. MODEL TINE 
HEIGHTS SHOW GOOD DRYING IN THE MID AND UPPER LEVELS WHICH SUPPORTS 
THIS CONCLUSION. HAVE NO REASON TO SIGNIFICANTLY CHANGE EXISTING 
GRIDS WHICH APPEAR TO HAVE THIS SCENARIO CAPTURED QUITE WELL.

.LONG TERM...(FRI NIGHT THROUGH THU)...MODELS CONTINUE TO INDICATE A 
CONVECTIVE COMPLEX MAY AFFECT MAINLY NORTHERN PARTS OF THE AREA LATE
FRI NIGHT INTO SATURDAY. WHILE CONFIDENCE NOT HIGH THAT THIS WILL 
HAPPEN...WILL BUMP POPS UP NORTH INTO THE LOW CHANCE RANGE FOR FRI
NIGHT...THEN WILL RUN WITH 20 POPS SW TO 50 POPS NE MTNS SAT.
SIGNIFICANT COLD FRONT FORECAST TO SWING THROUGH THE AREA ON SUNDAY.
DYNAMICS AND MOISTURE LOOK LIKE THEY WILL BE LIMITED...SO JUST CHANCE
POPS FOR NOW SUNDAY. WITH DRIER AIR MOVING IN AS HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN
FROM THE NORTH...WILL GO DRY SUN NIGHT AND MONDAY. LOOKS LIKE HIGH
PRESSURE WILL CONTINUE TO BE IN CONTROL THROUGH THU...WITH DRY WEATHER
EXPECTED.


&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN  72  93  73  95 /  40  30  20  20 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  71  91  72  93 /  50  30  20  30 
OAK RIDGE, TN  71  92  73  94 /  50  30  20  30 
TRI CITIES AIRPORT, TN  67  88  66  90 /  50  40  30  40

.DISCUSSION...NO CHANGES. KMRX RADAR SHOWS AREA OF PRECIP MOVING

CONTINUES TO LURK IN THE AREA...AND WITH ADDITIONAL DEVELOPMENT
TAKING PLACE IN WESTERN AND MIDDLE TENNESSEE...AM INCLINED TO NOT
LOWER POPS. FORECAST OTHERWISE APPEARS ON TRACK AND NO CHANGES ARE
WARRANTED AT THIS TIME.

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 180724
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
324 AM EDT THU AUG 18 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...FRONTAL BOUNDARYS TRAVELS WILL 
CONTINUE TODAY WITH A SLOW NORTHWARD SHIFT INTO SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA 
BY THIS EVENING. YET ANOTHER S/WV PRESSING THROUGH THE LOWER OHIO 
VALLEY WITH CONVECTION ONGOING ATTM PROGGED TO MOVE ACROSS THE 
FORECAST AREA TODAY. MODELS GO WILD WITH THE SCENARIO PUMPING UP 
POPS TO CATEGORICAL RANGE. DECIDED TO USE HIGH LIKELY POPS FOR 
NORTHERN THIRD OF THE FORECAST AREA WITH LOWER RANGE LIKELY ACROSS 
SOUTHEAST TENNESSEE AND SOUTHWEST NORTH CAROLINA. ITS HARD TO 
IMAGINE SUCH EXTENSIVE COVERAGE OF PRECIP IN A CONVECTIVE EVENT. AT 
ANY RATE BEST CHANCE FOR SHRA/TSRA SHOULD BE ACROSS NORTHERN 
CUMBERLAND PLATEAU/NORTHEAST TENNESSEE AND SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA IN 
AREA OF WAA ASSOCIATED WITH FRONT. DROPPED POPS OFF TONIGHT AS S/WV 
BUILDS E AND FRONT PUSHES AWAY TO THE NORTHEAST. TEMP GUIDANCE WAS 
BETTER YESTERDAY AND STAYED CLOSE TO BLEND OF SUGGESTED MAXES/MINS 
1ST TWO PERIODS OF THE FCST.



.LONG TERM...FRIDAY THRU DAY 7)...MODELS IN GOOD AGREEMENT ON FRIDAY BUT
SOME DISAGREEMENT BEGINNING FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY. NAM BRINGING
MODERATELY STRONG SHORT WAVE THROUGH THE NORTHERN PART OF THE FORECAST
AREA WITH ACCOMPANING HIGHER POPS. THIS IS A VERY REAL POSSIBILITY AND
HAVE INCREASED POPS IN THOSE AREAS TO COVER THIS POTENTIAL. KEEP THE
POPS IN TIL SUNDAYS FRONTAL PASSAGE. MODEL NUMBERS FINALLY BEGINNING TO
COME DOWN ON BOTH TEMPS AND POPS BEHIND THIS FRONT AND AGREE WITH THIS
TREND SO HAVE LOWERED BOTH IN THE CURRENT FORECAST CYCLE.


&&

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 180045
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
845 PM EDT WED AUG 17 2005

.DISCUSSION...CONVECTIVE COMPLEX IS HOLDING TOGETHER OVER MIDDLE TN 
AND IS MOVING EAST AT 10 TO 15 MPH...WITH THE LEADING EDGE OF THIS 
ACTIVITY JUST ENTERING WESTERN MOST PARTS OF OUR FORECAST/WARNING 
AREA.  WATER VAPOR SATELLITE PICS SUGGEST A SHORTWAVE IS AIDING 
THESE SHOWERS AND STORMS.  ISOLATED SMALL STORMS WELL IN ADVANCE OF 
THIS MAIN ACTIVITY HAVE VERY BRIEFLY PULSED UP TO MARGINAL SEVERE 
LEVELS.

MSAS SHOWS CONTINUED WEAK MOISTURE CONVERGENCE AND INSTABILITY 
ACROSS OUR REGION...SO EXPECT THIS ACTIVITY TO CONTINUE TO AFFECT 
MUCH OF THE REGION AT LEAST EARLY TONIGHT.  WILL CARRY POPS 
OVERNIGHT AND POSSIBLY INCREASE CHANCES IN WESTERN AREAS...OR ADD 
SCATTERED AREAL QUALIFIER TO THE WORDING.  GRIDS AND WEB PRODUCTS 
WILL ALSO GET A FRESHENING.  

&&

.MRX WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
NC......NONE.
TN......NONE.
VA......NONE.

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 171951
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
350 PM EDT WED AUG 17 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND THURSDAY)...SKIES HAVE BEEN PARTLY TO 
MOSTLY CLOUDY TODAY AS MOISTURE LINGERED WITH A STATIONARY FRONT 
OVER THE TENNESSEE VALLEY. DAYTIME HEATING INITIATED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS ON THE NORTHERN CUMBERLAND PLATEAU AND THEY ARE NOW 
SPREADING INTO THE CENTRAL VALLEY. A FEW HAVE DEVELOPED IN SOUTHWEST 
VIRGINIA...THE SMOKY MOUNTAINS AND IN SOUTHEAST TENNESSEE. HEAVY 
RAINFALL WITH A FEW STORMS AND POSSIBLY ISOLATED DAMAGING WINDS WITH 
STRONG STORMS UNTIL EARLY EVENING. WITH LOSS OF HEATING SHOWERS 
SHOULD DECREASE BUT A SHORTWAVE TRACKING THROUGH KY OVERNIGHT SHOULD 
AFFECT NORTHERN SECTIONS BY MORNING SO INCREASED CHANCES ALONG THE 
PLATEAU AND IN SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA. BELIEVE GFS IS OVERDOING THE 
STRENGTH OF THIS FEATURE THOUGH. THE SOUTHERN END OF THIS SHORTWAVE 
SHOULD AFFECT THE WHOLE FORECAST AREA THURSDAY WITH SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS LIKELY NORTH AND ABOUT 50 PERCENT COVERAGE SOUTH. MORE 
CLOUD COVER WILL KEEP HIGH TEMPERATURES COOLER...IN THE LOWER TO MID 
80S.  

.LONG TERM...(THU NIGHT THROUGH WED)...WITH WEAK BOUNDARY LINGERING 
OVER THE REGION ALONG WITH CONSIDERABLE MOISTURE...WILL GO WITH 30 
POPS SOUTH AND 50 NORTH CLOSER TO THE BOUNDARY ON FRIDAY.  WEAK 
RIDGE BUILDING IN ALOFT AHEAD OF NEXT TROUGH...AND MAY SEE SOME 
DRYING...SO JUST 20 POPS SAT.  COLD FRONT SHOULD PUSH THROUGH 
SUNDAY...WITH CHANCE POPS...THEN HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN FROM THE 
NORTH FOR MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY ALONG WITH MUCH DRIER AIR. WILL 
GO DRY FOR THE MON THROUGH WED PERIOD.  WILL NOT STRAY FAR FROM GFS 
MOS TEMPS THIS RUN. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             72  87  73  93 /  40  50  30  20 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  71  84  71  91 /  40  50  40  30 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       70  84  71  92 /  40  50  40  30 
TRI CITIES AIRPORT, TN              67  83  66  87 /  30  60  50  30

FXUS64 KMRX 171353
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
953 AM EDT WED AUG 17 2005

.DISCUSSION...A FRONTAL BOUNDARY REMAINS STATIONARY ACROSS THE 
TENNESSEE VALLEY THIS MORNING. IT SHOULD BE A FOCUS FOR SHOWER AND 
THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY TODAY AND TONIGHT. MODELS SHOW A SHORTWAVE 
MOVING THROUGH THE SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE FORECAST AREA THIS 
MORNING AND AFTERNOON AND ANOTHER SHORTWAVE MOVES ACROSS THE 
NORTHERN SECTIONS TONIGHT AND INTO THURSDAY. CURRENT SATELLITE  
SHOWS CONSIDERABLE CLOUDINESS SOUTH OF THE OHIO RIVER AND ACROSS THE 
TENNESSEE VALLEY. RADAR INDICATES A FEW SHOWERS IN NE AL MOVING 
SLOWLY SE AND ANOTHER AREA OVER SOUTH CENTRAL KY WHICH MAY MOVE INTO 
THE NORTHERN PLATEAU BY AFTERNOON AND THEN ACROSS CENTRAL SECTIONS. 
THE EARLY CLOUDS SHOULD LIMIT HEATING SOMEWHAT TODAY AND MAY DELAY 
ORGANIZED CONVECTION SLIGHTLY. CURRENT HOURLY TRENDS LOOK GOOD NO 
CHANGE TO CURRENT FORECAST.    

&&

FXUS64 KMRX 170737
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
336 AM EDT WED AUG 17 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...FRONTAL BOUNDARY REMAINS 
STATIONARY ACROSS THE SOUTHERN THIRD OF THE FORECAST AREA THIS 
MORNING AND SERVES AS A FOCUS FOR CONVECTION AGAIN TODAY AND TONIGHT 
AS A COUPLE OF S/WV FEATURES MAKE THEIR WAY EAST ACROSS THE MID 
SOUTH. REDUCED PROBABILITY OF SHRA/TSRA ACROSS SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA 
AND NORTHEAST TENNESSEE WHERE MODELS PROG LESS INSTABILITY AND MEAN 
RH. USED HIGHEST CHANCE POPS AREAS GENERALLY SOUTH OF INTERSTATE 40. 
STAYED CLOSE TO MOS BLEND CONCERNING MAX/MIN TEMPS. 


.LONG TERM...THE NEARLY STATIONARY FRONT WILL REMAIN OVER THE REGION
THROUGH THURSDAY PROVIDING A GOOD FOCUS FOR MOISTURE CONVERGENCE AND 
INCREASING SHOWER ACTIVITY CHANCE ABOVE CLIMATIC NORMALS. THE FRONT 
WILL FINALLY BEGIN TO LIFT OUT OF THE AREA ON FRIDAY WITH 
ACCOMPANIED LOWER RAIN PROBABILITIES GOING INTO THE WEEKEND. ANOTHER 
FRONTAL SYSTEM MAKES ITS WAY INTO THE FORECAST AREA ON SUNDAY WITH 
RAIN CHANCES AGAIN INCREASING. THIS FRONT HAS BETTER MOVEMENT AND 
SHOULD CLEAR THE REGION BY MONDAY. EVEN WITH THESE FRONTS MOVING 
THROUGH THE AREA THERE WILL BE ONLY MINOR INCREASES AND DECREASES IN 
TEMPERATURE OVER THE NEXT SEVEN DAYS.


&&

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 161944
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
344 PM EDT TUE AUG 16 2005

.SHORT TERM...ONGOING SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WATCH FOR 4 OF OUR VA COUNTIES
UNTIL EARLY EVENING. CONVECTION CONTINUES MOVING E ACROSS SE KY...BUT
CONVECTION HAS DIMINISHED IN INTENSITY AS IT MOVES INTO AN AREA WHERE
THE AIR MASS IS NOT AS STABLE AS FURTHER W. ADDITIONAL CONVECTION MOVING
E ACROSS PARTS OF W AND CENTRAL MIDDLE TN. SOME OF THIS CONVECTION MAY
MOVE INTO OUR W AREAS LATE THIS AFTERNOON OR EARLY EVE.

A WEAK COLD FRONT IS EXPECTED TO MOVE SE ACROSS MUCH OF THE AREA LATER
TONIGHT. SOME OF THE PRECIPITATION MENTIONED PREVIOUSLY SHOULD UNDERGO
SOME DISSIPATION AFTER DAYTIME HEATING ENDS THIS EVENING. HOWEVER...WITH
WNW UPPER LEVEL FLOW OVERNIGHT ALONG WITH SOME WEAK VORTICITY
AROUND...EXPECT THE CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND A FEW THUNDERSTORMS TO
PERSIST OVERNIGHT.

FRONTAL SYSTEM MAY MOVE JUST S OF OUR AREA BY DAYBREAK WED MORNING
...THEN REMAIN STATIONARY UNTIL IT BEGINS MOVING N AS A WARM FRONT 
WED NIGHT INTO THU. SO CHANCES OF RAIN WILL CONTINUE.

.LONG TERM...EARLY IN THE WEEKEND...A MORE SUMMER TYPE PATTERN TAKES HOLD
AGAIN BRIEFLY...AS UPPER LEVEL HEIGHTS ARE FORECAST TO INCREASE ACROSS
THE AREA IN RESPONSE TO UPPER LEVEL RIDGING THAT EXPANDS NE FROM
THE SOUTHERN PLAINS STATES.

UPPER FLOW HOWEVER DOES BEGIN TURNING MORE FROM THE W TO WNW OR NW 
BY SUNDAY MORNING AND CONTINUES THAT WAY THROUGH REST OF FORECAST
PERIOD...SO A CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS CAN BE EXPECTED
THROUGH THE PERIOD. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

OAK RIDGE, TN  71  88  70  85 /  60  50  40  50

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 161345
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
943 AM EDT TUE AUG 16 2005

.DISCUSSION...EXPECT MUCH MORE COVERAGE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
TODAY...GIVEN THE APPARENT UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT IN THE FORM OF A 
SHORTWAVE TROUGH (MCV) MOVING EAST ACROSS CENTRAL KY AND NRN MIDDLE 
TN.  THIS FEATURE LOOKS TO MOVE ACROSS THE FRONTAL BOUNDARY STILL 
STALLED E-W ACROSS SRN TIP OF IL AND NR KY AND W VA.  MODIFIED 12Z 
OHX AND RNK SOUNDINGS SHOW MODERATE INSTABILITY TODAY AND STEEP LOW 
LEVEL LAPSE RATES.  THUS...EXPECT GOOD COVERAGE ACROSS ESPECIALLY 
NRN PARTS OF THE FORECAST AREA...WITH STORMS LIKELY TO MOVE EAST AT 
10 TO 15 MPH.  SOME ISOLATED STRONG TO SEVERE STORMS SEEM POSSIBLE 
WITH DAMAGING DOWNBURST WINDS THE MAIN THREAT.

WILL UPDATE THE ZFPMRX TO REMOVE MORNING WORDING...AND ALSO ADD 
SCATTERED QUALIFIER WHERE LESS THAN LIKELY POPS ARE FORECAST FOR 
THIS AFTERNOON.  MOST OF FORECAST LOOKS ON TRACK FOR TODAY...BUT 
WILL FRESHEN THE GRIDS AND WEB PRODUCTS AS WELL.

MRX MAY BE GOING DOWN FOR UPGRADE TO AWIPS OB 6.0 THIS MORNING...IF
SO BACKUP WILL BE PERFORMED BY WFO NASHVILLE (OHX).



000 
FXUS64 KMRX 160724
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
324 AM EDT TUE AUG 16 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...QUASISTATIONARY BOUNDARY IN PLACE
ACROSS KENTUCKY AND SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA WILL MAKE A GRADUAL MOVE FARTHER
SOUTH INTO TENNESSEE DURING THE NEXT 24-36 HOURS AND WILL AID IN
FOCUSING CONVECTION ESPECIALLY ACROSS NRN PART OF THE FA INCLUDING THE
NRN CUMBERLAND PLATEAU/SW VA AND NE TN. S/WV PRESSING EAST ACROSS THE
LWR OH VLY WILL BUILD ONTO THE PLATEAU EARLY THIS AFTERNOON AND WILL
SHIFT TWD SW VA/NE TN BY LATE AFTERNOON. LIS/CAPE LOOK RATHER DECENT
FOR CONVECTION THIS AREA TODAY AND WITH S/WV FEATURE LIKELY POPS LOOK
GOOD 1ST PD. BUMPED UP POPS 2ND PD AS IT APPEARS THAT CONVECTION WILL BE
ONGOING AROUND 00Z AND WILL WEAKEN/DISSIPATE BY 04Z WITH LOSS OF
INSOLATION. STAYED PRETTY CLOSE TO PREVIOUS PACKAGE MAX/MIN TEMP 1ST TWO
PDS.


.LONG TERM...PERSISTENCE WILL CONTINUE TO BE THE MAIN FOCUS OF THE 
FORECAST THROUGH MOST OF THE PERIOD.  GFS INDICATES A WEAK FRONT 
MOVING INTO THE AREA ON WEDNESDAY AND HAVE INCREASED POPS BASED ON 
THIS FOCUS POINT.  THE FRONT LINGERS INTO THE WEEKEND AND HAVE KEPT 
POPS ABOVE SEASONAL NORMS BASED ON THIS. 

EVEN WITH THE SLIGHTLY HIGHER POPS...THERE SHOULD BE AMPLE SUNSHINE 
THROUGH THE PERIOD FOR WARMER THAN NORMAL VALUES.  WENT WITH HIGHS 
GENERALLY AROUND 90 FOR MUCH OF THE VALLEY FORECAST AREA WITH 
OVERNIGHT LOWS AROUND 70.

15/00Z MOS).

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 141857
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
300 PM EDT SUN AUG 14 2005

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND MONDAY)...LOW CLOUDS PERSISTED OVER THE MRX 
CWA FOR MUCH OF THE FIRST HALF OF THE DAY...LIMITING HEATING. 
HOWEVER...THE AIR MASS IS WEAK TO MODERATELY UNSTABLE WITH LOW LEVEL 
MOISTURE IN PLACE. SOME CONVECTION IS FORMING TO OUR WEST AND AS WE 
APPROACH CONVECTIVE TEMPERATURES...EXPECT SCATTERED CONVECTION TO 
DEVELOP OVER EAST TN. WEAK WAVES ALOFT AND OUTFLOW BOUNDARIES FROM 
YESTERDAY/S CONVECTION SHOULD AID DEVELOPMENT. DUE TO DIURNAL NATURE 
OF EXPECTED CONVECTION AND LATE START TO DEVELOPMENT...THUNDERSTORMS 
FORMATION MAY BE MORE LIMITED THAN PREVIOUSLY EXPECTED. FOR NOW... 
WILL LOWER POPS A BIT FOR THE EVENING...BUT MAY MAKE FURTHER 
ADJUSTMENTS...WILL MONITOR CUMULUS AND THUNDERSTORM INITIATION AND 
MAKE CHANGES AS RADAR AND SATELLITE IMAGERY DICTATE. AN APPROACHING 
BOUNDARY CURRENTLY POSITIONED OVER THE OHIO VALLEY REGION WILL VERY 
SLOWLY PUSH SOUTHWARD TOWARD THE MRX CWA ON MONDAY. MAIN FOCUS WILL 
REMAIN NORTH OF THE AREA THROUGH MONDAY...BUT CONVECTION OUT AHEAD 
OF THE BOUNDARY MAY BEGIN TO EFFECT NORTHERN ZONES BY THE AFTERNOON. 
THIS...COMBINED WITH EXPECTED NORMAL SUMMERTIME CONVECTION...WILL 
KEEP CHANCE POPS FOR MONDAY. PERSISTENCE LOOKS BEST WAY TO GO WITH 
TEMPS AND GUIDANCE IN LINE WITH THIS. 

.LONG TERM (MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...LATEST SHORT-RANGE MODEL 
RUNS INDICATE THAT A WEAK SHORT WAVE WILL NUDGE A QUASI-STATIONARY 
FRONT OVER THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY CLOSER TO THE FORECAST AREA ON 
TUESDAY. THIS SCENARIO SHOULD RESULT IN A LITTLE BETTER COVERAGE OF 
CONVECTION ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA...ESPECIALLY ACROSS SOUTHWEST VA 
AND NORTHEAST TN. OTHERWISE...UPPER-LEVEL FLOW SHOULD REMAIN MOSTLY 
ZONAL THROUGH THE WEEK WITH A STAGNANT MOIST AND MARGINALLY UNSTABLE 
AIRMASS CONTINUING THROUGH THE WEEK. THUS...EXPECT SCATTERED 
CONVECTION TO CONTINUE TO DEVELOP EACH DAY...MAINLY DURING THE 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING HOURS. ALSO...EXPECT A LITTLE BETTER COVERAGE 
OF CONVECTION OVER THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS DUE TO DIFFERENTIAL 
HEATING. 

LATEST GFS MODEL RUN NOW INDICATES THAT A STRONGER UPPER-LEVEL 
TROUGH WILL DEVELOP ACROSS SOUTHERN CANADA BY THE END OF THE WEEK... 
WHICH SHOULD RESULT IN A STRONGER COLD FRONT TOWARDS THE WEEKEND 
OVER THE FORECAST AREA. THE ENSEMBLE MEANS TEND TO SUPPORT THE GFS 
SOLUTION...SO WILL LOWER POPS A LITTLE ON SUNDAY WITH THE ASSUMPTION 
OF A FRONTAL PASSAGE BY THEN. AS FOR TEMPS...WILL PLAN TO GO WITH A 
PERSISTENCE FORECAST THROUGH MOST OF THE WEEK...BUT WILL LOWER TEMPS 
A LITTLE ON TUESDAY WITH AN INCREASE IN CLOUDS AND CONVECTIVE 
ACTIVITY EXPECTED.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
310 PM EDT SAT AUG 13 2005

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND SUNDAY)...LITTLE CHANGE IN WEATHER PATTERN 
WITH UPPER-LEVEL RIDGE THE MAIN WEATHER FEATURE AND AN EMBEDDED AREA 
OF LOW PRESSURE TO OUR SOUTH.  AIR MASS HAS BECOME UNSTABLE ONCE 
AGAIN THIS AFTERNOON WITH LI/S OF -3 TO -4.  MOISTURE REMAINS IN 
PLACE AND LIFT ASSOCIATED WITH WAVES CIRCULATING WITH THE LOW...AS A 
RESULT...SCATTERED CONVECTION HAS DEVELOPED IN AND AROUND THE MRX 
CWA.  THIS CONVECTION WILL CONTINUE INTO THE EVENING HOURS.  DAYTIME 
HEATING IS A STRONG INGREDIENT OF THE THUNDERSTORM DEVELOPMENT AND 
WITH SUNSET...ACTIVITY SHOULD DIMINISH.  HOWEVER...WEAK SHORT WAVES 
IN THE UPPER FLOW MAY KEEP SOME LIMIT CONVECTION GOING INTO THE 
OVERNIGHT HOURS.  MORE OF THE SAME EXPECTED FOR SUNDAY...WITH THIS 
NORMAL SUMMERTIME PATTERN IN PLACE OVER THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN 
REGION.  GUIDANCE NUMBERS LOOKS GOOD AND WILL NOT STRAY FAR FOR HIGH 
AND LOW TEMPS.  

.LONG TERM (SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY)...DOG DAYS OF SUMMER WILL 
CONTINUE THROUGH NEXT WEEK WITH A STAGNANT SYNOPTIC PATTERN EXPECTED 
FOR THE MOST PART. LATEST GFS MODEL RUN INDICATES THAT A WEAK SHORT 
WAVE ON TUESDAY MAY NUDGE A WEAK STATIONARY FRONT OVER THE OHIO 
RIVER VALLEY TOWARDS THE FORECAST AREA. HOWEVER...THINK THAT THIS 
FRONT SHOULD STAY NORTH OF THE FORECAST AREA THROUGHOUT THE WEEK... 
AS UPPER-LEVEL FLOW REMAINS MOSTLY ZONAL. A MOIST AND MARGINALLY 
UNSTABLE AIRMASS WILL CONTINUE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA...WITH 
SCATTERED CONVECTION EXPECTED TO DEVELOP EACH DAY NEXT WEEK...MAINLY 
DURING THE AFTERNOON AND EVENING HOURS. ALSO...EXPECT A LITTLE 
BETTER COVERAGE OF CONVECTION OVER THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS DUE TO 
DIFFERENTIAL HEATING. GFS MODEL ALSO INDICATES THAT A STRONGER 
UPPER-LEVEL TROUGH WILL DEVELOP LATER IN THE WEEK AND FINALLY PUSH A 
COLD FRONT INTO THE FORECAST AREA ON FRIDAY. HOWEVER...ENSEMBLE 
MEANS INDICATE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS TOO AGGRESSIVE WITH THE 
SOUTHWARD FRONTAL MOVEMENT...SO THINK THAT FRONTAL PASSAGE SHOULD BE 
SLOWER (SOMETIME NEXT WEEKEND). OVERALL...WILL PLAN TO GO WITH A 
PERSISTENCE FORECAST THROUGH NEXT WEEK.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
315 PM EDT FRI AUG 12 2005

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND SATURDAY)...CURRENT WEATHER PATTERN SHOWS A 
BROAD DOME OF HIGH PRESSURE ALOFT WITH A WEAK LOW OVER THE GULF 
STATES. ROTATION AROUND TO LOW IS FEEDING IN LOW LEVEL MOISTURE AND 
PROVIDING LIFT FOR THUNDERSTORMS FORMATION. CONVECTION IS DEVELOPING 
OVER OUR SOUTHERN CUMBERLAND PLATEAU AND AREAS SOUTH. AIR MASS IS

INSTABILITY IS SOUTH AND WEST OF THE MRX CWA. THROUGH THE EVENING 
HOURS...SCATTERED TO ISOLATED CONVECTION WILL CONTINUE...MAINLY OVER 
SOUTHERN ZONES. ACTIVITY SHOULD DIMINISH AFTER SUNSET...BUT ENERGY 
FROM THE LOW MAY KEEP SOME CONVECTION GOING INTO THE OVERNIGHT 
HOURS. ON SATURDAY...HIGH PRESSURE REMAINS THE DOMINANT WEATHER 
FEATURE AND WILL SEE ANOTHER HOT AND HUMID DAY. HOWEVER...MINOR 
HEIGHT FALLS SHOULD TRANSLATE INTO A DEGREE OR TWO COOLER THAN 
TODAY/S HIGHS. AIR MASS WILL AGAIN BECOME AT LEAST WEAKLY UNSTABLE 
IN THE AFTERNOON...AND THERMALLY DRIVEN THUNDERSTORMS SHOULD ONCE 
AGAIN DEVELOP.

.LONG TERM (SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY)...MODELS INDICATE THAT 
THE DOG DAYS OF SUMMER WILL CONTINUE THROUGH NEXT WEEK WITH A 
STAGNANT PATTERN EXPECTED. A MOIST AND MARGINALLY UNSTABLE AIRMASS 
WILL CONTINUE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA THROUGH NEXT WEEK...WITH 
SCATTERED CONVECTION DEVELOPING EACH DAY...MAINLY DURING THE 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING HOURS. ALSO...EXPECT A LITTLE BETTER COVERAGE 
OF CONVECTION ACROSS THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS. A COLD FRONT OVER THE 
MID WEST SHOULD REMAIN QUASI-STATIONARY OVER THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY 
THROUGH NEXT WEEK...AS THE UPPER-LEVEL FLOW REMAINS ZONAL AND AN 
UPPER-LEVEL RIDGE SLOWLY BUILDS OVER THE SOUTHEAST. LATEST TPC TRACK 
INDICATES THAT TROPICAL STORM IRENE WILL REMAIN OFF THE NORTH 
CAROLINA COAST ON TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY...WITH NO EFFECT ON THE 
FORECAST AREA. THUS...WILL PLAN TO GO WITH A PERSISTENCE FORECAST 
THROUGH FRIDAY WITH NO CHANGE IN THE LARGE-SCALE PATTERN EXPECTED.

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 111859
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
300 PM EDT THU AUG 11 2005

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND FRIDAY)...ISOLATED CONVECTION DEVELOPING TO 
OUR NORTH AND EAST. DEW POINTS HAVE CLIMBED BACK TO NEAR 70 AND THE 
AIR MASS IS MARGINALLY UNSTABLE. MAIN FOCUS OF THE CONVECTION SHOULD 
REMAIN NORTH AND EAST...BUT LIMITED DEVELOPMENT OVER THE THE MRX CWA 
IS POSSIBLE. SO...WILL INCREASE POPS ACROSS THE AREA TO AT LEAST 20 
PERCENT. THE ACTIVITY SHOULD BE DIURNAL IN NATURE AND EXPECT THE 
CELLS TO DISSIPATE WITH LOSS OF DAYTIME HEATING. ON FRIDAY...WE WILL 
BECOME WEAKLY UNSTABLE WITH STRONGER INSTABILITY EXPECTED TO OUR 
WEST. A MINOR WAVE WILL TRACK THROUGH TO OUR SOUTH AIDING THE 
POTENTIAL FOR AFTERNOON/EVENING CONVECTION. MAIN AREA FOR POSSIBLE 
THUNDERSTORM DEVELOPMENT IS EXPECTED ACROSS OUR SOUTHERN ZONES...SO 
WILL INCREASE THOSE POPS TO CHANCE CATEGORY. 850MB TEMPS CONTINUE TO 
RISE OVER THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION INTO FRIDAY AFTERNOON FOR 
ANOTHER HOT AND HUMID DAY. GUIDANCE NUMBERS LOOK REASONABLE AND WILL 
STAY CLOSE TO THESE.

.LONG TERM (FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY)...MODELS INDICATE THAT 
MOISTURE AND INSTABILITY WILL SLOWLY INCREASE FOR THE WEEKEND..WITH 
A LITTLE BETTER COVERAGE OF CONVECTION EXPECTED IN THE AFTERNOON AND 
EVENING HOURS. A COLD FRONT OVER THE MID WEST SHOULD REMAIN QUASI- 
STATIONARY OVER THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY THROUGH THE MIDDLE OF NEXT 
WEEK...AS THE UPPER-LEVEL FLOW REMAINS ZONAL. HOWEVER...GFS MODEL 
INDICATES THAT A SHORT WAVE WILL HELP TO NUDGE THIS FRONT TOWARDS 
THE FORECAST AREA NEXT WEEK. LATEST TPC TRACK INDICATES THAT 
TROPICAL STORM IRENE WILL APPROACH THE NORTH CAROLINA COAST BY 
TUESDAY MORNING...BUT SHOULD BE MOVING NORTH BY THAT TIME. THUS...IT 
APPEARS AT THIS TIME THAT THERE WILL BE LITTLE IMPACT ON THE 
FORECAST AREA OTHER THAN TO KEEP THE QUASI-STATIONARY FRONT OVER THE 
OHIO RIVER VALLEY WEST AND NORTH OF THE AREA. WILL PLAN TO KEEP A 
CHANCE OF MAINLY DIURNAL CONVECTION THROUGH THURSDAY...WITH A MOIST 
AND MARGINALLY UNSTABLE REMAINING ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. THE BEST 
COVERAGE OF CONVECTION SHOULD CONTINUE TO BE ALONG THE HIGHER 
ELEVATIONS. AS FOR TEMPS...WILL GO WITH A PERSISTENCE FORECAST 
THROUGH THE WEEKEND WITH THE STAGNANT AIRMASS...BUT WILL LOWER MAXES 
FOR NEXT WEEK AS CLOUDS AND MOISTURE INCREASE AHEAD OF THE COLD 
FRONT AND IRENE.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

OAK RIDGE, TN                       70  91  70  89 /  10  20  30  40

PRECIPITATION...LEAVING IT ONLY IN UPSLOPE AREAS OF PLATEAU AND 
APPALACHIANS.


.LONG TERM...(FRIDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...PREFER THE ETA/NAM HANDLING 
OF WHAT SHORT RANGE MODELS SUGGEST WILL BE A WEAK MID/UPR LEVEL LOW 
OR TROUGH AXIS ACROSS ERN GULF COAST STATES FROM LATE FRIDAY INTO 
THE WEEKEND. DONT SEE MUCH MORE THAN ISOLATED CONVECTION AT BEST 
FOR FRIDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING...AND WOULD LIKE TO KEEP THE 
SAT/SUN POPS AT NO MORE THAN LOW END OF CHANCE FOR NOW. THUS...KEPT 
CURRENT POP/WX GRIDS BELOW MOS VALUES THROUGH THE WEEKEND. MOISTURE 
LOOKS TO GRADUALLY INCREASE NEXT WEEK...BUT DIFFICULT TO PIN DOWN OR 
TIME HOW MUCH CONVECTIVE PCPN OCCURS EACH DAY.

OTHERWISE...SOME PRELIMINARY GRIDS CREATED FOR NEXT THURSDAY...WHICH 
ARE CERTAINLY SUBJECT TO CHANGE.  LATEST NHC TRACK FOR TROPICAL 
STORM IRENE IS APPROACHING NC COAST EARLY WEDNESDAY.

FXUS64 KMRX 101914
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
315 PM EDT WED AUG 10 2005

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND THURSDAY)...PRETTY MUCH MAINTAINED PREVIOUS 
FCST IDEOLOGY FOR THESE PERIODS ADJUSTING POPS A LITTLE HIGHER THIS 
EVENING FOR EXTREME SOUTHEAST TENNESSEE AND SOUTHWEST NORTH CAROLINA 
CLOSER TO CONVERGENT AREA ASSOCIATED WITH SFC TROF AND DEEPER 
MOISTURE. CONVECTION FIRING MAINLY SOUTH AND EAST OF THESE ZONES 
WHERE COVERAGE OF STORMS IS 50 PERCENT OR GREATER. OPTED FOR A 30 
PERCENT POP HERE AND USED SLGT CHC ELSEWHERE FOR THE EVENING 
DROPPING OFF AFTER MIDNIGHT. DEEPEST MOISTURE MAY SHIFT EVER SO 
SLOWLY FARTHER SOUTH AND EAST ON THURSDAY BUT SUFFICIENT MOISTURE/ 
INSTABILITY STILL AVAILABLE FOR WIDELY SCATTERED CONVECTION MAINLY 
VICINITY OF MAJOR TERRAIN AREAS AND MAINTAINED SLGT CHC POP FORECAST 
AREA-WIDE. STAYED CLOSE TO GUIDANCE FOR MIN TEMPS TONIGHT ADDING A 
DEGREE MOST AREAS AND TRIMMING A DEGREE OR TWO FROM SUGGESTED MAXES 
THURSDAY.

.LONG TERM (THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...A STAGNANT AIRMASS 
WILL REMAIN OVER THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION THROUGH THE MIDDLE 
OF NEXT WEEK...AS SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE REMAINS ENTRENCHED OVER THE 
SOUTHEAST WITH UPPER-LEVEL FLOW REMAINING MOSTLY ZONAL. BECAUSE OF 
THIS ZONAL FLOW ALOFT...A COLD FRONT OVER THE MID WEST SHOULD STALL- 
OUT OVER THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY AND REMAIN QUASI-STATIONARY THROUGH 
THE WEEKEND. LATEST GFS MODEL RUN INDICATES THAT A WEAK UPPER-LEVEL 
TROUGH WILL DEVELOP OVER THE PLAINS BY MONDAY...WHICH SHOULD HELP 
PUSH THIS STATIONARY FRONT FARTHER EAST TOWARD THE FORECAST AREA BY 
WEDNESDAY. ALSO...LATEST HPC TRACK FOR TROPICAL SYSTEM IRENE BRINGS 
IT ALONG THE CAROLINA COAST BY WEDNESDAY...WITH THE FORECAST AREA 
BECOMING LOCATED IN BETWEEN IRENE AND THE COLD FRONT. RIGHT NOW... 
ITS TOO EARLY TO KNOW IF IRENE WILL HAVE ANY EFFECT ON THE FORECAST 
AREA. THUS...WILL PLAN TO KEEP A CHANCE OF MAINLY DIURNAL CONVECTION 
THROUGH WEDNESDAY...WITH A MOIST AND MARGINALLY UNSTABLE REMAINING 
ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. AS FOR TEMPS...WILL GO WITH A PERSISTENCE 
FORECAST THROUGH THE WEEKEND...SINCE THE LOCAL AIRMASS SHOULD REMAIN 
MOSTLY UNCHANGED. FOR THE FIRST PART OF NEXT WEEK...WILL LOWER MAXES 
SOME EACH DAY SINCE CLOUDS AND MOISTURE SHOULD INCREASE AHEAD OF THE 
COLD FRONT AND IRENE.
&&

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 100651
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
251 AM EDT WED AUG 10 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...RELATIVELY DRY PERIOD CONTINUES 
AS FORECAST AREA REMAINS SITUATED BETWEEN WEATHER FEATURES TO THE 
NORTH AND SOUTH. ONCE AGAIN...GFS GUIDANCE POPS SEEM OVERDONE BASED 
ON ITS OWN TIME HEIGHT DEPICTION OF DRY MOISTURE PROFILE AND GENERAL 
SUBSIDENCE. THUS WILL UNDERCUT GFS GUIDANCE AND REMOVE POPS FROM 
MOST VALLEY LOCATIONS AND CONFINE LOW POPS TO HIGHER TERRAIN. THE 
EXCEPTION WILL BE THE SOUTHERN VALLEY AS IT REMAINS CLOSER TO 
STALLED SURFACE BOUNDARY ACROSS GEORGIA. NAM PROJECTS ANOTHER FRONT 
WILL APPROACH THE FORECAST AREA FROM THE NORTH LATE IN THE SECOND 
PERIOD. HOWEVER...TIMING REMAINS QUESTIONABLE AND GFS AND 
SHORT-RANGE ENSEMBLES PROJECT BOUNDARY TO REMAIN NORTH OF THE AREA 
THROUGH THE SHORT TERM. FOR TEMPS...GUIDANCE VALUES GENERALLY AGREE 
QUITE WELL. TENDED TO FAVOR BLEND FOR THE MOST PART.


.LONG TERM...(THURSDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...CHALLENGING TO PICK A 
PERIOD WHERE ANY BETTER THAN ISOLATED (MAINLY DIURNAL) CONVECTIVE 
PRECIPITATION (PCPN) WOULD OCCUR THURSDAY INTO THE WEEKEND.  SHORT 
RANGE MODELS...MAINLY ETA/NAM...SUGGEST A WEAKENING MCS MAY DROP SE 
ACROSS MUCH OF KY INTO MIDDLE AND NE TN AROUND OR AFTER 12Z THURSDAY.
NOT SURE IF I WANT TO BUY INTO THIS COMPLETELY WITH ZONAL FLOW TO 
OUR NORTH AND RIDGE BUILDING OVER SE STATES AT THAT TIME.  FOR NOW 
...DID TOSS IN SOME VERY MINIMAL POPS (15-20%) FOR OUR NE PLATEAU 
COUNTIES AND LEE/WISE OF VA TO MESH BETTER WITH JKL AND RLX LATEST 
GRIDS.  OTHERWISE...DECIDED BEST COURSE WAS TO GENERALLY STICK WITH 
THE 20 TO 30 PERCENT POPS AS IN CURRENT GRIDS THROUGH THE WEEKEND.

FOR EARLY NEXT WEEK...UPPER TROUGH DEVELOPING ACROSS PLAINS STATES 
WILL HELP TO CREATE MORE OF A SW FLOW IN THE MID TO UPPER LEVELS...
AND LIKELY INCREASE THE DEPTH OF MOISTURE FOR MORE INSTABILITY.  
HOWEVER...THE WEAK COLD FRONT LOOKS TO LIKELY REMAIN TO OUR NORTH.
THUS...I LIKED THE CHANCE POPS FOR NOW MONDAY THRU WEDNESDAY.  SOME
PRELIMINARY GRIDS WERE MADE FOR THE NEW DAY 7 (WEDNESDAY). 

FOR TEMPS...MAX TEMPS NEAR THE BLEND OF MOS LOOKED GOOD FOR THU AND 
FRI...EXCEPT WHERE THIS BLEND WOULD BE BELOW PERSISTENCE PLUS A 
DEGREE OR TWO EACH DAY.   

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             91  71  93  72 /  20  10  20  20


000 
FXUS64 KMRX 090715
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
315 AM EDT TUE AUG 9 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...SLOW DRYING TREND IS EXPECTED TO 
CONTINUE TODAY AS WEAK UPPER TROUGH CONTINUES TO DRIFT EAST. GFS IS 
SLOWER WITH THIS PROCESS AND THUS THE WETTEST...WHILE NAM IS 
FASTER/DRIER. SHORT-RANGE ENSEMBLES DEPICT MAINLY DIURNAL PRECIP 
OVER THE FORECAST AREA. DIFFERENCES ARE REFLECTED IN HIGHER POPS 
PROJECTED BY GFS GUIDANCE. MID-LEVEL DRYING DEPICTED BY GFS TIME 
HEIGHTS CASTS SOME DOUBT ON THE RELATIVELY HIGH POPS PROJECTED BY 
ITS GUIDANCE. NEVERTHELESS...MORE BREAKS IN OVERCAST AS SUGGESTED BY 
MID- AND UPPER-LEVEL DRYING WILL ALLOW BETTER SURFACE HEATING. THUS 
DIURNAL COVERAGE AS DEPICTED BY SHORT-RANGE ENSEMBLES SEEMS MOST 
APPROPRIATE. AS A RESULT...GENERALLY FAVORED BLEND OF GUIDANCE 
VALUES FOR POPS. FOR TEMPS...GENERALLY FAVORED GFS GUIDANCE BASED ON 
RECENT HISTORY.

.LONG TERM...(WEDNESDAY THROUGH TUESDAY)...RAIN CHANCES WERE LOWERED 
SLIGHTLY FROM WEDNESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY...SINCE THE WEAK UPPER 
LEVEL TROUGH IS PROGD TO LIFT NE OF THE REGION BY WEDS AFTERNOON... 
AND ALL SHORT RANGE MODELS KEEP THE WEAK COLD FRONT TO OUR NORTH.
GENERALLY GAVE THE WX/POP GRIDS A DIURNAL LOOK FOR THOSE PERIODS
DONT SEE THE MAX TEMPS CLIMBING AS FAST AS THE ETA/NAM MOS INDICATES
...AND AS MENTIONED IN SHORT RANGE THE MAV/GFS MOS HAS PERFORMED 
BEST OF LATE.  POSSIBLY AT LEAST SOME PATCHY AREAS OF FOG LATE 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT...IF SKIES CLEAR SUFFICIENTLY UNDER VERY LIGHT 
WINDS...BUT DID NOT ADD TO GRIDS JUST YET.    

OTHERWISE...LEFT FRIDAY INTO MONDAY GRIDS UNCHANGED FOR NOW.  BY THE 
NEW DAY 7...ALL LONG RANGE MODELS CURRENTLY INDICATE UPPER TROUGH TO 
OUR WEST WITH AN ASSOCIATED STRONGER COLD FRONT LURKING JUST TO THE 
NW.  GRIDS MADE FOR TUESDAY LEAD TO CHANCE POPS AREAWIDE BY THE 
AFTERNOON AND LINGER INTO THE EVENING HOURS.  


&&

MOISTURE. ALSO THINK BETTER CHANCE OF STORMS TUESDAY VERSUS
TODAY...STILL AWAITING FIRST CG TODAY IN OUR CWA.

CLOUDS SHOULD HANG IN MOST OF THE NIGHT TONIGHT TO KEEP FOG FROM GETTING
TOO THICK OVER MUCH OF THE AREA.

SHOULD GET WARMER TUESDAY AS WELL AS SOUPY AIR MASS STARTS TO RETREAT.


.LONG TERM...(TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY)...WEAK SURFACE BOUNDARY 
AND UPPER TROUGH LINGERING INTO TUESDAY NIGHT AND WEDNESDAY...WILL 
KEEP CHANCE POPS GOING BOTH PERIODS.  MODELS SHOWING DECREASING 
MOISTURE BY WEDNESDAY NIGHT...WILL KEEP LOW CHANCE POPS FOR EARLY 
WEDNESDAY EVENING...THEN 20 POPS AFTER MIDNIGHT.  RIDGE BUILDS IN 
BRINGING DRIER WEATHER.  MAY STILL SEE ISOLATED ACTIVITY IN THE 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING HOURS FOR THURSDAY AND FRIDAY.  THE RIDGE 
RECEDES A BIT ON SATURDAY...WITH SHORTWAVES ROTATING THROUGH...WILL 
GO WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS ON SATURDAY AND CHANCE POPS ON SUNDAY AND 
MONDAY.

FXUS64 KMRX 080717
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
317 AM EDT MON AUG 8 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...A SLIGHTLY SOGGY NIGHT CONTINUES 
ACROSS MUCH OF THE FORECAST AREA...ALTHO GENERALLY VERY LIGHT RAINS 
AND NO THUNDER.  THE 08/00Z UPPER AIR PLOTS SHOW THE MID TO UPPER 
LEVEL LOW PRESSURE CENTER LOCATED BETWEEN BMX AND FFC...WHICH WILL 
PROVIDE ANOTHER DAY OF OCCASIONAL SHOWERS FOR OUR REGION.  DID 
CONTINUE JUST A SLIGHT CHANCE OF THUNDERSTORMS THIS AFTERNOON AND 
EARLY EVENING.  THE E-SE LOW LEVEL FLOW WILL PROVIDE EXTRA LIFT AND 
CONVERGENCE FOR HIGHER TERRAIN AREAS...ESPECIALLY SRN MTNS AND 
PLATEAU.  CONCERNING THE PREVIOUS FFA FOR CHEROKEE AND CLAY NC...
I GENERATED 24 HR PCPN ESTIMATES FROM BOTH KHTX AND KMRX.  RADAR 
ESTIMATES OVER ERN CLAY COUNTY NC WERE AROUND 1.5 TO 2.0 INCHES FOR 
24 HRS ENDING AT 04Z TODAY...AND MUCH LESS FROM WRN CLAY COUNTY INTO 
CHEROKEE COUNTY.  THESE AREAS HAVE EXPERIENCED A FEW HOURS BREAK 
WITH NO PCPN AT ALL...AND THINK THAT RAINS TODAY AND EARLY TONIGHT 
WONT BE EXCESSIVE ENOUGH TO CAUSE ANY SIGNIFICANT FLOOD PROBLEMS.

OTHERWISE...RAISED POPS ABOUT 10 TO 20 PERCENT GENERALLY ACROSS THE 
BOARD TODAY...ENDING UP WITH CATEGORICAL VALUES FOR THE SRN 3/4THS 
OF THE FORECAST AREA BY THIS AFTERNOON.  THE UPPER LOW DRIFTS NORTH 
AND THE ESE LOW LEVEL UPSLOPE FLOW WEAKENS CONSIDERABLY...SO I 
CONTINUED WITH A DECREASING TREND IN POPS FOR LATE TONIGHT.  CLOUDS 
AND PCPN YESTERDAY REALLY PUT A LID ON MAX TEMPS...ALTHO MAV MOS WAS 
NOT TOO FAR OFF THE MARK.  TEMPTED TO UNDERCUT EVEN THE COOLER MAV 
HIGHS FOR TODAY...BUT THOSE NUMBERS WERE REASONABLE SO I STAYED NEAR 
OR JUST A DEGREE OR TWO BELOW MAV MAX TEMPS.  MINS LOOKED JUST ABOUT 
IN LINE WITH PREVIOUS GRIDS.  FWC MOS WINDS CAPTURED THE CURRENT 
WEAK NE OR E SURFACE WINDS BEST AND WERE USED.


.LONG TERM...UPPER LEVEL SHORTWAVE CONTINUES TO INFLUENCE THE REGION
THROUGH TUESDAY BEFORE EXITING THE REGION WEDNESDAY. KEPT POPS ABOVE
SEASONAL NORMS TUESDAY DROPPING BACK TO NORMAL LEVELS BY THURSDAY.
TEMPERATURES WILL QUICKLY REBOUND TO LOWER 90S/UPPER 80S BY MID WEEK.

TO 15 MPH...FAST ENOUGH TO LIMIT AREAS OF LOCALLY HEAVY RAINS.

CONVECTIVE PCPN CERTAINLY FAVORS GOING CLOSER TO THE COOLER MAV MOS

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 060719
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
319 AM EDT SAT AUG 6 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...WEAK FRONTAL BOUNDARY WHICH 
APPEARS TO BE LOCATED ROUGHLY ACROSS THE SRN THIRD OF KY INTO SW VA 
THIS MORNING...MAY HELP TO FOCUS CONVECTIVE DEVELOPMENT THIS 
AFTERNOON.  HOWEVER...SHORT RANGE MODELS ALSO DEPICT CONTINUED WEAK 
ESE LOW LEVEL FLOW INTO THE MTN AREAS...DUE TO FLOW BETWEEN THE 
SURFACE RIDGE TO THE NE AND WEAK SURFACE LOW THAT IS PROGD TO 
DEVELOP OVER THE GULF COAST STATES (MAINLY MS/AL).  I WOULD EXPECT 
BEST CONVERGENCE TO BE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS FRONT OVER NRN MOST 
AREAS AND IN THE MTNS.  MOS POPS SEEMED A BIT LOW...SO NUDGED THESE 
FAVORED AREAS UP TO THE HIGHEST END OF CHANCE POPS WITH SCATTERED 
WORDING FOR THIS AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING.  VALLEY POPS MAY NOT 
BE HIGH ENOUGH CONSIDERING THAT STORM MOTION SHOULD BE W OR NW AT 10 
MPH OR LESS...WHICH SHOULD LET STORMS DRIFT OUT OF THE MTNS TOWARD 
THE VALLEY.  THE WEAK UPPER LOW TO OUR SOUTH...WHICH HPC STATES IS 
HANDLED BETTER BY GFS THAN NAM...MIGHT KEEP CONVECTION GOING 
OVERNIGHT...ALTHO STILL THINK THAT CONVECTION WILL FAVOR DIURNAL 
HOURS. 

YESTERDAYS PCPN PATTERN FOR 24 HOUR RAINFALL FROM MIDNIGHT TO 
MIDNIGHT ONCE AGAIN GENERALLY SHOWED BEST COVERAGE OVER PLATEAU...
SWRN VA AND ERN MOST HIGH TERRAIN AREAS.  ONE SURPRISE AREA OF HEAVY 
RAINS OCCURED IN CENTRAL EAST TN OVER PARTS OF ROANE AND LOUDON 
COUNTIES...WHERE BOTH HTX AND MRX RADARS ESTIMATED AS HIGH AS 4 TO 6 
INCHES OF RAIN MAY HAVE FALLEN.  LOCAL STORM REPORTS ALSO INDICATED 
SOME WET DOWNBURSTS DOWNED A FEW TREES YESTERDAY.  WILL LIKELY 
MENTION SOME LOCALLY HEAVY RAINS TODAY AND ISOLATED DAMAGING WINDS 
WITH STRONGEST STORMS IN THE HWO PRODUCT.

OTHERWISE...THINKING THAT COOLER MOS MAX TEMPS FOR TODAY SHOULD BE 
FAVORED GIVEN THE INCREASE IN MOISTURE CONVERGENCE OVER A LARGE AREA.
MIN TEMPS TONIGHT IN GRIDS WERE CLOSE TO LATEST MOS VALUES AND 
GENERALLY FOLLOWED.  CARRIED A MENTION OF PATCHY FOG EARLY THIS 
MORNING GIVEN THE LOCALLY HEAVY RAINS AND LACK OF CLOUDINESS AT THIS 
TIME.   

.LONG TERM...WEAKENING FRONT WILL LINGER TO THE NORTH OF THE REGION WITH
CONTINUED MOISTURE CONVERGENCE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA WILL HAVE
CONTINUED ELEVATED PRECIPITATION CHANCES MAINLY IN THE AFTERNOON AND
EVENING HOURS. VERY LITTLE FOCUS OTHER THAN AFTERNOON SCATTERED
CONVECTION SO LIMITED DEVIATION FROM GUIDANCE VALUES.

.DISCUSSION...SCATTERED SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS ARE CONTINUING 
INTO THE EVENING...THOUGH EXPECT SOME DECREASE IN COVERAGE WITH LOSS 
OF HEATING.  AN APPROACHING BOUNDARY REMAINS WELL TO OUR NORTH AND 
IS MAKING VERY SLOW PROGRESS SOUTHWARD.  WITH THE SLOWER MOVEMENT... 
THE BOUNDARY SHOULDN/T HAVE SIGNIFICANT INFLUENCE OVER AREA WEATHER 
TONIGHT.  HOWEVER...MODELS BRINGING A WEAK WAVE INTO THE REGION 
OVERNIGHT FOR AT LEAST CONTINUED SLIGHT CHANCE POPS.  ALL ON TRACK 
IN THE CURRENT FORECAST...WILL UPDATE ZONES TO REMOVE EVENING 
WORDING.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
247 PM EDT FRI AUG 5 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT)...DIFFERENTIAL HEATING 
AND OROGRAPHIC FLOW PULSING GOOD UPDRAFTS DURING PEAK HEATING ONCE 
AGAIN THIS AFTN/EVE. A PATTERN SHIFT HAS EVOLVED WHICH WILL AFFECT 
WEATHER THROUGH THE REMAINDER OF THE SHORT TERM. WEAK BOUNDARY AT 
EDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE TO THE NORTH WILL SINK DOWN INTO N MRX CWA ON 
SAT. LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM ALONG N GLFMEX BECOMING BETTER DEFINED 
THROUGH SUNDAY. SYSTEM WILL DRIFT N IN TN VLY AND WEAKEN BY LATER IN 
THE PERIOD. THIS DEVELOPMENT WILL ENHANCE UPR DIFFLUENCE OVR THE 
AREA AND INCREASE SE FLOW AND DEEPEN MOISTURE. MORE CLOUD COVER AND 
HIGHER POPS ARE IN THE OFFERING. MODEL THICKNESS VALUES APPEAR TO 
DROP EXCESSIVELY ACROSS THE AREA AND CLOUD COVER LOOKS OVERDONE. 
STAYED ON THE HIGH SIDE OF MOS TEMP GUIDANCE.

.LONG TERM...(MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...GFS INDICATING FRONT LIFTING 
SLOWLY NORTH FOR THE FIRST PART OF THE WEEK.  SHOULD BRING SCATTERED 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY...WILL BUMP UP 
POPS TO 40 PERCENT ON MONDAY AND TUESDAY WITH DECENT MOISTURE 
EXPECTED.  GFS INDICATING DRIER WEATHER PUSHING IN ON THURSDAY... 
BUT STILL MAY SEE ISOLATED DIURNAL ACTIVITY ON THURSDAY AND 
FRIDAY...SO WILL KEEP 20 POPS FOR BOTH DAYS.

AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1030 AM EDT FRI AUG 5 2005

.DISCUSSION...FORECAST ON TRACK. NO UPDATE PLANNED. 

SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...SHORT RANGE MODELS OVERALL SEEM 
TO BE REASONABLE IN KEEPING MAIN CONVECTIVE PCPN TO OUR NORTH CLOSER 
TO THE WEAK COLD FRONT (CURRENTLY ACROSS THE OHIO VALLEY REGION) 
TODAY AND EVEN SO AGAIN TONIGHT.  GENERATED USER SELECTABLE PCPN 
PRODUCTS FROM KHTX AND KMRX FOR 24 HOURS ENDING AT 05/00Z...AND 
BELIEVE CONVECTION WILL PROBABLY STICK CLOSE TO THESE SAME AREAS 
AGAIN.  BEST COVERAGE WAS ACROSS THE CUMBERLAND PLATEAU INTO LEE AND 
WISE COUNTIES OF SW VA...AND OTHERWISE ACROSS THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS 
ALONG THE TN-NC STATE LINE.  PREVIOUS WX/POP GRIDS LOOKED QUITE GOOD 
FOR TODAY AND TONIGHT...WITH JUST A SLIGHT DECREASE MADE OVER NRN 
MOST VALLEY LOCATIONS.  DO FEEL THAT BY SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND 
EVENING THE FRONTAL BOUNDARY WILL BE NEAR ENOUGH...POSSIBLY NUDGING 
JUST INTO THE FORECAST AREA...TO BE MORE OF A FOCUS FOR DEVELOPMENT 
OF SHRA/TSRA.  

OTHERWISE...LATEST OBSERVATIONS DONT SEEM TO BE TRENDING DOWNWARD 
ENOUGH IN VSBY TO JUSTIFY MENTIONING PATCHY FOG IN THE GRIDS/ZFP
THIS MORNING...SO WILL JUST MONITOR AND COVER WITH SHORT TERM 
FORECASTS IF NEEDED.  MAX TEMPS NUDGED JUST UP A DEGREE OR TWO... 
CLOSER TO YESTERDAYS MAX TEMPS AND GENERALLY A BLEND OF THE MAV/FWC 
VALUES.  MIN TEMPS FOR TONIGHT LOOKED QUITE GOOD AND CLOSE TO LATEST 
MOS VALUES.


LONG TERM...BEST ESTIMATES KEEP FRONT JUST NORTH OF THE FORECAST 
AREA. IT WILL REMAIN A FOCUS POINT FOR MOISTURE CONVERGENCE BUT WITH 
LIMITED LIFT FOCUS. THIS MOISTURE IS ENOUGH TO KEEP MODERATE POPS 
THROUGH PERIOD AND SLIGHTLY COOLER TEMPS WITH INCREASED CLOUD COVER. 
STAYED NEAR GFS GUIDANCE NUMBERS.

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...HIGH PRESSURE RIDGE OVER MUCH OF 
THE SOUTHERN U.S. WILL REMAIN IN CONTROL OF THE WEATHER ACROSS THE 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION TODAY.  LITTLE CHANGE IN FORECAST WITH 
CONTINUED STRONG DAYTIME HEATING EXPECTED TO PUSH AFTERNOON HIGHS 
BACK INTO THE 90S ONCE AGAIN ACROSS MOST VALLEY LOCATIONS.  AIR MASS 
IN PLACE WILL AGAIN BECOME UNSTABLE THIS AFTERNOON.  HOWEVER...WITH 
SUBSIDENCE...WARM TEMPS ALOFT AND NO DECENT CONVECTIVE TRIGGER... 
EXPECT ANOTHER DAY WITH ONLY A FEW ISOLATED THERMALLY DRIVEN 
CELLS...MAINLY OVER HIGHER TERRAIN. 


.LONG TERM...(FRI THROUGH WED)...MODELS IN REASONABLY GOOD AGREEMENT
THROUGH THE LONG TERM. WEAK FRONT APPROACHES THE REGION BY THE WEEKEND
SHOULD STALL OUT BEFORE PROGRESSING INTO THE AREA. FRONT EVENTUALLY
DISSIPATES BUT PROVIDES SOME MOISTURE AND WEAK FOCUS FOR CONVECTION
THROUGH MUCH OF THE PERIOD. THUS HAVE CONTINUED CHANCE POPS THROUGH
EARLY NEXT WEEK. ANTICIPATE COVERAGE TO GRADUALLY DECREASE TO
SEASONAL NORMS BY LATE IN THE PERIOD AS BOUNDARY DISSIPATES AND UPPER
SUPPORT WEAKENS AND PULLS NORTHEASTWARD AWAY FROM OUR AREA.

REASONABLE AND WERE GENERALLY FOLLOWED CLOSELY.

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION
SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO 
DOMINATES AREA WEATHER THROUGH THE SHORT TERM.  NO TRIGGERING 
MECHANISM SHOWING IN EITHER MODELS OR SATELLITE TO INITIATE 
CONVECTION TODAY.  AT BEST...STRONG HEATING MAY INDUCE SOME DIURNAL 
CONVECTION OVER HIGHER TERRAIN.  HOWEVER...WITH STRONG SUBSIDENCE 
AND FURTHER WARMING ALOFT...PROBABILITY OF CONVECTIVE DEVELOPMENT 
REMAINS LOW AND WOULD BE LIMITED.  THE STRONG HEATING EXPECTED THIS 
AFTERNOON SHOULD PLACE AFTERNOON TEMPERATURES A DEGREES OR TWO ABOVE 
TUESDAY/S.

LONG TERM...(THU THROUGH TUE)...MODELS CONTINUE TO BE IN DECENT 
AGREEMENT IN SHOWING BROAD RIDGE DOMINATING OUR WEATHER THU 
THU...WITH FAIRLY DRY AIR IN PLACE OVER THE AREA.  MAY BE A FEW 
THUNDERSTORMS IN THE TN AND NC MTNS...ALTHOUGH DO NOT EXPECT 
MUCH...SO JUST SLIGHT CHANCE POPS THERE...DRY ELSEWHERE THROUGH THU 
NIGHT.  COLD FRONT DRAWS CLOSER FRIDAY...AND MOISTURE INCREASES BY 
AFTERNOON.  LOOKS LIKE FRONT WILL STALL NOT FAR FROM OUR NORTHERN 
COUNTIES...AND WILL SLOWLY DISSIPATE THROUGH THE WEEKEND.  WILL GO 
WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL VALLEY...CHANCE NORTH 
AND MOUNTAINS FRI...THEN CHANCE ALL ZONES SAT AND SUN.  NO 
SIGNIFICANT CHANGES TO LATER PERIODS AT THIS TIME.

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE

STAGNANT AND DRY PATTERN EXPECTED TO CONTINUE. WITH THE LACK OF ANY 
STRONG TRIGGERING MECHANISMS EXPECTED...THINK THAT ISOLATED DIURNAL 
CONVECTION SHOULD BE LIMITED TO THE MOUNTAINS. AS FOR TEMPS...WILL 
GENERALLY FOLLOW A PERSISTENCE FORECAST THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT.

.LONG TERM...(FRIDAY THROUGH TUESDAY)...COLD FRONT MOVES THROUGH 
OHIO VALLEY FRIDAY AND THEN TRIES TO APPROACH THE TENNESSEE VALLEY 
LATE AFTERNOON AND FRIDAY NIGHT BEFORE GETTING HUNG UP WITH RIDGING 
OVER THE SOUTHEAST AND SOUTH CENTRAL STATES. THE FRONT BECOMES 
STATIONARY OVER THE CENTRAL APPALACHIANS THIS WEEKEND AND THEN DISSIPATES
EARLY NEXT WEEK AS HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS OVER THE SOUTHEAST. MOISTURE
INCREASES WITH THE PROXIMITY OF THE FRONT SO WILL INTRODUCE POPS INTO
THE VALLEYS AND INCREASE FOR THE MOUNTAINS FRIDAY. MORE CLOUD COVER AND
RAIN WILL LOWER HIGHS SEVERAL DEGREES ESPECIALLY IN THE MOUNTAINS.   
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             68  92  69  92 /   0   0   0   0

OAK RIDGE, TN                       65  90  66  90 /   0   0   0   0

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...MODELS GRADUALLY BUILD RIDGE

RH VALUES S. USED A CONSERVATIVE APPROACH MAINTAINING SLGT AND CHC 
TYPE POPS FOR TERRAIN AREAS AND MAINLY SRN THIRD OF THE FA TUE AND 
THEN KEEPING JUST SLGT CHC POP FOR MTNS BORDERING NC AND THE SRN 
THIRD OF FA ON WED ALLOWING FOR POSSIBILITY THAT SHEAR AXIS DOESNT 
EXIT QUITE AS RAPIDLY AS MODELS SUGGEST. REMAINDER OF THE FCST GETS 
A LITTLE MURKY AS UPR TROF MIGRATES E ACROSS CANADA BUILDING INTO 
THE GREAT LAKES REGION THU/FRI WITH FRONTAL BOUNDARY SUGGESTED TO 
DROP S TWD THE TN VLY/APPALACHIANS BY THE WEEKEND. AHEAD OF THE 
BOUNDARY GFS SHOWS A LITTLE BIT STRONGER UPR LVL NW FLO AROUND 
CENTRAL AND WESTERN STATES RIDGE HINTING AT MCS TYPE ACTION THU/FRI. 
WENT AHEAD AND USED A LOW CHC POP THU-SUN TO COVER POSSIBILITY OF 
ISOLD-SCT DIURNAL CONVECTION DURING THIS PERIOD AND KEEP A 
SUGGESTION OF UNSETTLED WEATHER WITH UPR TROF PRESSING INTO NERN 
U.S. TEMP GUIDANCE APPEARED TO BE A TAD ON THE WARM SIDE IN THE 
EXTENDED AND ADJUSTED MAXES/MINS BACK SLIGHTLY.

AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
254 PM EDT SUN JUL 31 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
CURRENTLY SCATTERED ACROSS THE EASTERN MOUNTAINS AND WIDELY 
SCATTERED ACROSS THE SOUTHERN PLATEAU. ISOLATED SHOWERS AND STORMS 
WERE LOCATED ACROSS SW VA AND A FEW ALONG THE NORTHERN PLATEAU. NOT 
MUCH CHANGE TO THE CURRENT FORECAST EXPECT TO LOWER POPS SLIGHTLY IN 
THE CHA AREA FROM 50 TO 40 PERCENT EARLY. WITH STORMS MOVING SLOWLY 
SOUTHWEST IT LOOKS LIKE THE BEST COVERAGE WILL BE ACROSS THE 
SOUTHERN THIRD OF THE FORECAST AREA. DRIER AIR THAT WAS LOCATED TO 
THE WEST HAS BEEN REPLACED BY MORE HUMID CONDITIONS. DEWPOINT 
BOUNDARY HAS SHIFTED NORTH FROM SOUTHERN WV ACROSS CENTRAL KY TO 
SOUTHERN MO. STRONG UPPER RIDGE CONTINUES OVER THE WESTERN AND SOUTH 
CENTRAL STATES WITH WEAK TROUGHING OVER THE NORTHEAST. THE BERMUDA 
HIGH REMAINS OFF THE SOUTHEAST COAST. SURFACE HIGH LIES OVER THE 
EASTERN GREAT LAKES AND MOST OF THE OHIO VALLEY. A WEAKNESS WILL 
CONTINUE BETWEEN THE BERMUDA HIGH AND RIDGE TO THE WEST AND CONTINUE 
TO BRING MOISTURE INTO THE FORECAST AREA AS LIFT OCCURS NEAR THE 
MOUNTAINS DURING THE HEATING OF THE DAY FORMING SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS AND THEN MOVES THEM WEST TO SOUTHWEST INTO THE VALLEYS 
OR IN OTHER WORDS ABOUT THE SAME AS YESTERDAYS ACTIVITY. LOCALIZED 
HEAVY RAINFALL AND A FEW STRONG STORMS WILL BE POSSIBLE. 

.LONG TERM...(MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...MED RANGE MODELS SHOWED RIDING
BUILDING INTO THE CENTRAL APPALACHIANS EARLY WEEK WITH SOME DRYING TAKING
PLACE INITIALLY ACROSS SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA AND NORTHEAST TENNESSEE. 
ALSO...EASTERLY WINDS ON THE BOTTOM OF THE CENTRAL APPALACHIAN HIGH 
WILL PRODUCE WEAK DOWNSLOPE WINDS INTO THE NORTH AND CENTRAL VALLEY. END
RESULT WILL BE MINIMAL CHANCES OF AFTERNOON/EVENING CONVECTION FOR 
TRI AND TYS AREAS THROUGH WEDNESDAY. BEST CHANCES OF CONVECTION WILL 
BE ACROSS THE SOUTH...FAR EASTERN TENNESSEE MOUNTAINS (GENERALLY 
SMOKYS SOUTHWARD)...AND PLATEAU WHERE MOISTURE WILL BE A LITTLE 
DEEPER AND SOME UPSLOPE FLOW IS ANTICIPATED.

FOR LATE FRIDAY INTO NEXT WEEKEND...MODELS HINT OF A WEAK/DISSIPATING
FRONT MOVING INTO THE FORECAST AREA WITH INCREASING PWS. WILL 
INCREASE POPS TO CHANCE AREA-WIDE FOR SATURDAY AND SUNDAY. 
HOWEVER...CONFIDENCE OF FRONT MAKING IT INTO THE REGION LOW GIVEN 
TIME OF THE YEAR.

AS FOR TEMPERATURES...MORE SEASONAL HIGHS AND LOWS ANTICIPATED. DOWNSLOPE
INTO THE NORTHERN HALF OF THE GREAT TENNESSEE VALLEY WILL ADD A FEW 
DEGREES.

TEMPS.

.LONG TERM (MONDAY THROUGH SATURDAY)...NAM/GFS GENERALLY MAINTAIN 
THEIR RESPECTIVE SOLUTIONS FOR THE NEXT FEW DAYS WITH THE NAM NOT 
QUITE AS PESSIMISTIC AS THE GFS IN TERMS OF THE USE OF HIGHER POPS. 
BOTH MODELS SHOW SFC THRU UPR LVL RIDGING GRADUALLY BUILDING ACROSS 
THE FA FROM THE OH VLY THRU 12Z WED WITH INVERTED LOW LVL TROF 
PRESSING W ACROSS THE SERN U.S. DONT BELIEVE ATMOSPHERE WILL BE 
QUITE AS DRY AS NAM INDICATES THROUGH THE EARLY PART OF THE EXTENDED 
FCST BUT ALSO CANT BUY INTO THE BROADBRUSH TECHNIQUE SUGGESTED BY 
THE GFS WHICH SHOWS EXCESSIVELY HIGH MEAN RH AND QPF ACROSS MOST OF 
THE FA. SO WENT CLOSER TO THE NAMS BETTER RESOLUTION IN AN EASTERLY 
FLO REGIME AS INVERTED TROF PROGRESSES SLOWLY W INTO MID/WRN TN WITH 
LOWER POPS ACROSS SW VA/NE TN VLY AND HIGHER IN THE MTNS BORDERING 
NC AND ACROSS SE TN. ALSO ADDED SOME SLGT CHC POPS TO THE NRN 
CUMBERLAND PLATEAU ZONE WHERE EASTERLY FLO COULD AID ISOLD 
CONVECTION. LOWERED POPS TO SLGT CHC ACROSS NRN/CNTRL VLY/MTN ZONES 
ON FRI AND RAISED TO CHC CATEGORY ON SAT AS GFS SHOWS UPR TROF 
DRAGGING COOL FNT TWD THE APPALACHIANS. STAYED FAIRLY CLOSE TO CLIMO 
FOR MAX TEMPS THRU THE PD EVERYWHERE BUT SE TN/SW NC THROUGH THU 
WHERE DEEPER MOISTURE AND POSSIBLE SCT CONVECTION MAY SLOW WARMING 
BY A COUPLE DEGREES.

COULD BRING SOME STORMS THAT FORM IN THE SRN APPS INTO VALLEY LOCATIONS.
THINK THAT POSSIBILITY IS HIGHEST IN SE TN. MODELS SHOW UNCAPPED
SOUNDINGS AT MAX HEATING WITH 1000-1500 J/KG CAPE. THINK MODELS MAY BE
UNDERPLAYING SUBSIDENCE ON BACK SIDE OF UPPER TROUGH AS SEEN ON WV LOOP.
WILL LIMIT POPS TO MINIMAL NUMBERS TODAY AND A JUST A FEW % POINTS
HIGHER ON SUNDAY. THINKING THAT AS LONG AS UPPER TROUGH IS STUCK EAST OF
AREA PRECIP WILL BE SPOTTY AT BEST.  

TEMPS LOOK TO BE A LITTLE WARMER TODAY WITH MORE SUNSHINE EXPECTED. MADE
ONLY MINOR ADJUSTMENTS TO PREVIOUS SET OF TEMP GRIDS.


.LONG TERM (MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...RIDGING TRIES TO ESTABLISH 
ITSELF FROM THE OH VLY THROUGH THE MIDDLE ATLANTIC STATES GENERALLY 
THROUGH THE FIRST HALF OF THE PERIOD WHILE MODELS DEVELOP SOME 
INVERTED LOW LVL TROFFING FROM THE N CNTRL GULF MEX INTO THE MID 
SOUTH. THE GFS DOES THIS TO A GREATER EXTENT THAN THE NAM AND IT 
APPEARS THAT THE GFS IS SUFFERING FROM CONVECTIVE FEEDBACK WHICH 
MAKES ITS SOLUTION A BIT SUSPECT IN REGARDS TO THIS TROF AND 
CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT OF WEAK AREA OF LO PRES ACROSS WRN/MID TN. OF 
COURSE GUIDANCE PUMPS UP POPS AS HIGH AS LIKELY CATEGORY TUE-THU 
PERIOD IN GFS REGIME BUT DIDNT BUY INTO THIS SCHEME AND MAINTAINED 
VERY LOW POPS OR EVEN REMOVED FROM NRN/CNTRL VLY THROUGH THE EARLY 
PART OF THE FCST PD AND KEPT SLGT/CHC TYPE POPS GOING IN MTNS 
BORDERING NC AND ACROSS THE SRN VLY WHERE PROGGED ELY FLO SUPPORTS 
MOISTURE TRANSPORT AND OROGRAPHIC LIFT INTO THESE AREAS. ALSO 
MAINTAINED A SLGT CHC POP IN NRN CUMBERLAND PLATEAU COUNTIES WHERE 
THIS WIND PATTERN MAY LEAD TO SOME OROGRAPHIC LIFT IN THIS AREA. 
TRIED TO KEEP A VERY GRADUAL WARMING TREND GOING INTO MID WEEK AND 
THEN HOLD CLOSE TO CLIMATOLOGY WED-FRI. SUGGESTED MEX MOS MAX/MINS 
LOOKS A FEW DEGREES TOO WARM MOST AREAS TUE-THU AND STAYED BELOW.



&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
318 PM EDT FRI JUL 29 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS 
SHOWS HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE GREAT LAKES AND OHIO VALLEY AND A WEAK 
COLD FRONT OVER THE SOUTHEAST STATES. THE FRONT LOOKS TO BE 
SOMEWHERE NEAR THE APPALACHIAN CREST. DRIER AIR IS LAGGING BEHIND 
THE FRONT ABOUT 150 MILES WITH LOWER DEWPOINTS FROM THE PLATEAU 
WEST. TEMPERATURES ARE ABOUT 5 DEGREES COOLER TODAY AT THE SAME TIME 
AS YESTERDAY AND CLOUDS HAVE HELD IN KEEPING CONVECTION MORE 
LIMITED. RUC MODEL INDICATES MAIN SHORTWAVES ARE ACROSS NORTH AL AND 
WESTERN NC. RADAR INDICATING MAINLY SHOWERS OVER HIGHER TERRAIN OF 
SW VA AND NE TN AND ALSO THE SOUTHERN PLATEAU AND MOUNTAINS OF 
SOUTHEAST TN AT MID AFTERNOON. AGREE MORE WITH NAM GUIDANCE WITH  
LESS PRECIPITATION COVERAGE TONIGHT THAN YESTERDAY AND ONLY SLIGHT 
CHANCE SHOWERS IN THE FOOTHILLS AND CHANCE IN THE EASTERN MOUNTAINS 
TOMORROW AS BEST LIFT AND SHORTWAVES WILL BE EAST OF THE 
APPALACHIANS. TEMPERATURES SHOULD BE A LITTLE WARMER SATURDAY WITH 
LESS CLOUD COVER TOO. 


.LONG TERM...(SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY)...DEEPER MOISTURE STAYS 
JUST TO OUR E AND S...ALTHO SUFFICIENT LINGERING MOISTURE AND 
INSTABILITY FOR SOME CONCERN THAT CONVECTIVE PRECIPITATION (PCPN) 
COULD DEVELOP OUTSIDE OF THE MTN AREAS OVER THE WEEKEND.  THE UPPER 
FLOW IS NEARLY ZONAL ACROSS THE NRN MOST STATES...WITH RIDGING 
ACROSS THE WRN STATES...WHICH PLACES OUR FORECAST AREA IS THE 
USUALLY TROUBLESOME WEAK NW FLOW ALOFT.  GFS AND NGM MODELS DEPICT 
AT LEAST LIGHT QPF SPREADING BACK WEST INTO OUR AREA BY SUNDAY... 
WHILE ETA/NAM WOULD KEEP ANY PCPN CONFINED TO OUR ERN MTNS 
EASTWARD.  AT THE SURFACE...MODELS EITHER SHOW A WEAK SURFACE LOW 
DEVELOPING ALONG THE MAIN FRONTAL BOUNDARY TO OUR SOUTH...OR PERHAPS 
JUST A WEAK TROUGH AXIS NWD INTO WRN PARTS OF THE FORECAST AREA.  
CURRENT GRIDS ARE MORE IN LINE WITH ETA/NAM...WITH GENERAL AGREEMENT 
AND FIT WITH NEIGHBORING GRIDS (DID MAKE SLIGHT POP ADJUSTMENTS TO 
MESH WITH FFC...GSP AND RNK INTO MONDAY).

OTHERWISE...UPPER RIDGE DOES NOT SEEM TO BUILD INTO THE REGION INTO 
NEXT WEEK (KEEPING WEAK NW FLOW ALOFT)...AND TIME HEIGHT SECTIONS 
SHOW CONSIDERABLE MOISTURE...SO I KEPT OUR MAX TEMPS A LITTLE BELOW 
HPC VALUES.  WENT CLOSE TO HPC POPS FOR THU AND FRI...BUT IF UPPER 
LEVEL TROUGH DOES DEVELOP BY LATE THURSDAY INTO FRIDAY...THEN POPS 
WILL NEED TO BE RAISED.  HOWEVER...BOTH THE UPPER LEVEL AND SURFACE 
PATTERNS MAKE IT DIFFICULT TO FORECAST WITH A GOOD DEGREE OF 
CONFIDENCE AT THIS POINT.

EXPECTED TO NUDGE UPPER TROUGH FARTHER EAST. GENERAL AGREEMENT BETWEEN
MODELS THAT BY 12Z SAT UPPER TROUGH WILL BE EAST OF MOUNTAINS. GETTING
BACK TO FRONTAL LOCATION...THINK THAT FRONT WILL HOLD WEST AT LEAST
UNTIL AFTER EARLY AFTERNOON DEEP CONVECTION STARTS...THEREFORE HAVE
BUMPED UP THE POPS ON THE PLATEAU FOR THIS AFTERNOON. AFTER INITIAL
STORMS MOVE TO EAST THINK SHOW WILL BE OVER FOR THE MOST PART FOR

12Z. MADE ONLY 1-2 DEGREE TWEAKS TO PRFEVIOUS TEMP/DEWPOINT GRIDS.

.LONG TERM (SATURDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...SFC BOUNDARY LINGERS JUST S 
AND E OF THE FA EARLY IN THE PERIOD BUT MOVES AWAY JUST OFF THE 
SOUTHEAST ATLANTIC COAST BY SATURDAY NIGHT/SUNDAY. LOWERED POPS 
AREAWIDE EVEN DROPPING ACROSS MOST OF THE FA THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT AS 
AIRMASS DRIES A BIT ON UPPER NW FLO AS UPR TROF SLIPS E TO THE 
PIEDMONT/COASTAL PLAIN. KEPT SOME SLGT AND LOW CHC POPS ALONG MTNS 
BORDERING NC THROUGH THIS PERIOD AS MOISTURE/INSTABILITY STILL 
REMAINS HIGH ENOUGH ALONG WITH OROGRAPHIC LIFTING TO KEEP MENTION OF 
A SHRA/TSRA IN FCST. LOW LVL ELY FLO DEVELOPS LATE IN THE WEEKEND 
AND STRENGTHENS INTO TUESDAY AND THEREFORE SLGT THROUGH CHC POPS 
WERE RE-APPLIED FA AREA-WIDE. GFS INDICATES PRESSURES INCREASE 
TUESDAY NIGHT INTO THURSDAY NIGHT ACROSS THE OH VLY THROUGH THE MID 
ATLANTIC BRINGING COOLER GREAT LAKES AIRMASS TO A HALT ALONG WITH 
ITS ATMOSPHERIC LIFTING ABILITIES. EVER SO SLIGHTLY TWEAKED MAX/MIN 
TEMPS UP DURING THIS PERIOD AS RIDGING BUILDS. MAINTAINED SLGT CHC 
POPS FROM PREVIOUS PACKAGE DO TO UNCERTAINTY AT THIS LONGER TIME 
RANGE.

.LONG TERM...(THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...UPPER LEVEL TROUGH 
DEVELOPING FROM ERN CANADA SOUTHWARD...IS SHOWN TO EXTEND INTO THE 
TN VALLEY BY 12Z FRIDAY...THEN SOUTHERN END OF THIS TROUGH LINGERS 
WELL INTO THE WEEKEND.  THIS FACTOR PLUS SOME UNCERTAINTY AS TO HOW 
FAR SOUTH THE WEAK COLD FRONT PUSHES...LEADS TO THE NEED TO CARRY AT 
LEAST CHANCE POPS INTO MONDAY.  DECIDED TO CARRY LOWER END OF LIKELY 
POPS FOR EXTREME ERN MOST MTNS DAYTIME FRIDAY DUE TO EXPECTED 
CONVERGENCE...AND TO ALSO BETTER MESH WITH NEIGHBORING GRIDS FROM 
GSP/RNK.  

BY TUESDAY...THERE WOULD APPEAR TO BE JUST A WEAK SHEAR AXIS LEFT OF 
THE UPPER TROUGH...WITH HEIGHTS STARTING TO RISE INTO WEDS.  ANOTHER 
WEAK FRONT NOTED ON HPC PROGS COULD BE A WEAK FOCUS FOR CONVECTIVE 
DEVELOPMENT BY THAT TIME...BUT THIS IS TOO FAR OUT TO TIME WITH ANY 
CONFIDENCE.  CONSENSUS FROM NEIGHBORING OFFICES WAS TO GENERALLY 
LOWER POPS TO BELOW CLIMO FOR TUE AND WED...WHICH WORKED OUT TO LESS 
THAN 30 PERCENT CHANCE FOR OUR FORECAST AREA.

THIS COLD FRONT SHOULD THEN STALL-OUT OVER THE FORECAST AREA BY 
TONIGHT...WITH SCATTERED CONVECTION AGAIN DEVELOPING ACROSS THE 
FORECAST AREA ON THURSDAY. THIS FRONT SHOULD REMAIN QUASI-STATIONARY 
AROUND THE MOUNTAINS THROUGH EARLY NEXT WEEK...WITH A CHANCE OF 
CONVECTION CONTINUING ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA EACH DAY...ESPECIALLY 
ACROSS THE MOUNTAINS. TEMPS SHOULD REMAIN NEAR NORMAL THROUGH THE 
FORECAST PERIOD.

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS REVEALS A LARGE AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE

THIS MORNING...BUT IT SHOULD GRADUALLY BEGIN TO WEAKEN TODAY AS AN 
UPPER TROUGH DEVELOPS OVER THE UPPER MS RIVER VALLEY AND PUSHES A 
COLD FRONT TOWARDS THE REGION. MOS TEMP GUIDANCE CONTINUES TO INSIST 
THAT TEMPS WILL RISE INTO THE 95 TO 100 DEGREE RANGE ACROSS MOST OF 
THE FORECAST AREA TODAY...BUT WILL GENERALLY FORECAST HIGHS TO RISE 
ONLY A DEGREE ABOVE YESTERDAYS READINGS. ALTHOUGH THE SOIL MOISTURE 
HAS BEEN SLOWLY DRYING WITH MOSTLY SUNNY SKIES EXPECTED...THINK THAT 
THE WEAKENING UPPER HIGH AND POSSIBLE HIGH CLOUD DEBRIS FROM ANY
ISOLATED CONVECTION SHOULD KEEP TEMPS FROM WARMING TOO MUCH ABOVE 
THOSE OBSERVED YESTERDAY. WITH A MODERATELY UNSTABLE AIRMASS 
EXPECTED TO DEVELOP THIS AFTERNOON AND SUBSIDENCE BEGINNING TO RELAX 
A BIT...THINK THAT ISOLATED CONVECTION COULD DEVELOP THIS AFTERNOON 
AND EVENING ACROSS THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS.

ON WEDNESDAY...THE COLD FRONT SHOULD BE LOCATED GENERALLY ALONG THE 
OHIO RIVER VALLEY...AND MOVE INTO THE FORECAST AREA DURING THE 
AFTERNOON HOURS. A MODERATELY UNSTABLE AIRMASS IS EXPECTED TO 
DEVELOP ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA AHEAD OF THIS FRONT...AND THINK 
THAT A FEW SEVERE TSTORMS WITH DAMAGING WINDS WILL BE POSSIBLE. 
LATEST GFS MODEL RUN INDICATES THAT THIS COLD FRONT WILL STALL-OUT 
ALONG THE MOUNTAINS...WHICH IS MORE REALISTIC THAN YESTERDAYS 
SOLUTION WHICH SHOWED THE FRONT STALLING-OUT OVER THE CAROLINAS. 
THUS...IT APPEARS THAT A CHANCE OF CONVECTION WILL CONTINUE ACROSS 
THE FORECAST AREA THROUGH EARLY NEXT WEEK...ESPECIALLY ACROSS THE 
MOUNTAINS.

AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
338 AM EDT MON JUL 25 2005

.SHORT TERM (TODAY THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS 
REVEALS A LARGE AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE CENTERED OVER THE SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIAN REGION...WITH A WARM AND HUMID AIRMASS REMAINING OVER 
THE FORECAST AREA. A STRONG UPPER-LEVEL HIGH CENTERED OVER THE LOWER 
MS RIVER VALLEY THIS MORNING...WILL CONTINUE TO SLOWLY MOVE EAST 
OVER THE FORECAST AREA TODAY AND TUESDAY. MOS TEMP GUIDANCE 
CONTINUES TO INSIST THAT TEMPS WILL RISE INTO THE 95 TO 100 DEGREE 
RANGE TODAY AND TUESDAY ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. THE FAIRLY HIGH 
SOIL MOISTURE CONTENT AND HIGH CLOUD DEBRIS FROM CONVECTION OVER THE 
GREAT LAKES AND MID ATLANTIC REGIONS HAVE LIKELY BEEN THE CULPRITS 
FOR THE COOLER TEMPS OBSERVED OVER THIS WEEKEND. WITH THE UPPER- 
LEVEL HIGH EXPECTED TO BECOME CENTERED OVER THE FORECAST AREA THIS 
AFTERNOON...THINK THAT TEMPS SHOULD RISE A FEW DEGREES HIGHER THAN 
YESTERDAY. HOWEVER...WILL STILL PLAN TO UNDERCUT ALL GUIDANCE BY 
THREE TO FOUR DEGREES. ALTHOUGH CLOUDS SHOULD INCREASE A LITTLE BIT 
ON TUESDAY...THINK THAT HIGHS WILL BE FAIRLY SIMILAR TO TODAYS 
EXPECTED HIGHS...SINCE THE SOIL MOISTURE CONTENT WILL BE SLOWLY 
DRYING OUT. 

AS FOR POSSIBLE CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY...MODELS REVEAL A VERY UNSTABLE 
AIRMASS DEVELOPING THIS AFTERNOON...BUT STRONG SUBSIDENCE ALOFT WITH 
THE UPPER HIGH SHOULD SUPPRESS ANY CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY TODAY AND 
TONIGHT. ON TUESDAY...SUBSIDENCE BEGINS TO RELAX A BIT...SO THINK 
THAT ISOLATED CONVECTION COULD DEVELOP...MAINLY ACROSS THE HIGHER 
ELEVATIONS.


.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...ON WEDNESDAY CAPPING INVERSION
WILL CONTINUE TO WEAKEN AND WOULD EXPECT UNSTABLE AIR MASS TO RESPOND
WITH GOOD COVERAGE OF STORMS EARLY WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON. DONT KNOW IF MODE WILL
BE A LINE OF STORMS SINCE...FRONT MAY NOT BE IN CWA YET...AS MUCH AS
SIMPLY CONVECTION STARTING IN LOCALLY FAVORED AREAS...ESPECIALLY ON THE
PLATEAU THEN MOVING ENEWD IN FLOW. WEDNESDAY EVENING THINK THE FRONT
WILL GET INVOLVED AND VERY WELL COULD GET A LINE OF STORMS ACROSS THE
AREA. FOR PEAK HEATING ON WEDNESDAY...EXPECTING CAPE VALUES AOA 2500
J/KG IF WE CAN GET UP TO FORECAST HIGH TEMPS.

THINK FRONT WILL MAKE IT MOST OF THE WAY ACROSS CWA WEDNESDAY
NIGHT...BUT MAY HANG IN MOUNTAINS THURSDAY...FINALLY THURSDAY NIGHT
LOOKS SAFE TO SAY FRONT WILL BE SOUTH/EAST OF CWA. WITH UPPER TROF
SETTLING INTO AREA...UNSETTLED WX WITH SOME CONVECTION CAN BE EXPECTED
INTO THE WEEKEND.

FXUS64 KMRX 241915
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
315 PM EDT SUN JUL 24 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY)...TEMPS ACROSS SWRN VA AND 
NE TN ARE FINALLY STARTING TO HEAT UP...HAVING BEEN INHIBITED BY 
PATCHY MID TO HIGH CLOUDS FOR MUCH OF THE DAY.  HEAT INDICES OTHER 
THAN AT CHA...HAVE YET TO GO ABOVE UPPER 80S TO LOWER 90S.  SHOULD 
BE ANOTHER DAY THAT WE OUT PERFORM MOS WHICH HAS BEEN TOO HOT EACH 
DAY.  HOWEVER...BELIEVE THAT OUR FORECASTED HIGHS WILL END UP CLOSE 
FOR TODAY...WITH A LITTLE WARMING TOMORROW AND SLIGHTLY HIGHER HEAT 
INDICES.  LOW LEVEL FLOW BECOMES WEAK SW BY TUESDAY AND TIME HEIGHT 
SECTIONS SHOW AN INCREASE IN LOW LEVEL MOISTURE.  HOWEVER...RIDGING 
HOLDS STRONG AND THE WARM AIR ALOFT SHOULD STILL SERVE TO CAP ANY 
SIGNIFICANT CONVECTION FROM DEVELOPING.  THUS...DECIDED TO LIMIT 
POPS (20% OR SO) TO JUST THE HIGHER TERRAIN AREAS TUESDAY AFTERNOON.
POPS WERE REMOVED FROM ALL VALLEY LOCATIONS FOR TUESDAY AFTERNOON.

OTHERWISE...FOR TONIGHT...CLOUDS HAVE THINNED BUT KEPT JUST A FEW 
MORE CLOUDS IN THE FAR NE AREAS...IN CASE MORE CONVECTION DEVELOPS 
OVER CENTRAL APPALACHIANS AND DRIFT OUR WAY.  TOSSED IN PATCHY 
VALLEY FOG IN AREAS THAT HAVE EXPERIENCED SOME LATE NIGHT FOG OVER 
THE PAST COUPLE OF MORNINGS.  KEPT MINS VERY NEAR PERSISTENCE VALUES.

ONLY MINOR TWEAKS MADE TO REMAINING HIGHS AND LOWS EACH PERIOD...
GENERALLY STAYING ABOUT 1 TO 3 DEGREES BELOW THE HOTTER MAX TEMPS.  
THE SEGMENTED SPS WAS ALREADY UPDATED...AND ALL GRID/WEB PRODUCTS 
HAVE BEEN SENT FOR THE AFTERNOON PACKAGE.


.LONG TERM...(TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...RIDGING DROPS 
SOUTHEAST TO THE GULF/ATLANTIC COASTAL REGION BY WEDNESDAY ALLOWING 
A SLOW RETURN OF DEEP MOISTURE AHEAD OF FRONTAL BOUNDARY WHICH IS 
BELIEVED TO MAKE PROGRESS INTO THE FA ON THURSDAY. WILL USE HIGHEST 
POPS 30-40 PERCENT WED/THU WITH FRONTAL MOVEMENT INTO THE REGION AND 
THEN TAPER BACK TO SLIGHT CHANCE ESPECIALLY NORTHERN SECTIONS 
INCLUDING THE NORTHERN CUMBERLAND PLATEAU AND SW VA/NE TN FRI-SUN AS 
DRIER AIR FILTERS INTO THIS AREA AND MAINTAIN SLIGHT TO CHANCE TYPE 
POPS DURING THIS PERIOD FOR THE SOUTHERN HALF OF THE FA AS THE 
FRONTAL BOUNDARY SLIPS INTO THIS REGION AND WEAKENS BY SUNDAY. 
STAYED A FEW DEGREES BELOW MEX MOS MAX TEMP GUIDANCE AS IT APPEARS 
THAT THERMO NUCLEAR WARMING IT HAS BEEN SUGGESTING FOR THE PAST 
SEVERAL DAYS IS OUT TO LUNCH AND BELIEVE THIS TREND WILL MAINTAIN 
ITSELF.

ACROSS SW VA AND NE TN WHERE SOME SLIGHT DRYING OF DEWPOINTS 
OCCURRED...AND GENERALLY IN THE UPPER 60S TO LOWER 70S ACROSS MUCH 
OF THE REMAINING AREAS.  14Z TEMPS SEEM TO BE RUNNING A DEGREE OR 
TWO BEHIND YESTEDAY...BUT EXPECT THIS TREND TO BE QUICKLY OVERCOME 
AS 12Z OHX/RNK SOUNDINGS SHOW VERY WARM AIR IN THE LOW LEVELS.  THE 
CAPPING INVERSION LOOKS EXTREMELY STRONG FROM OHX SOUNDING...SO IN 
SPITE OF A SLIGHT INCREASE IN PRECIPITABLE WATER...NO CONVECTIVE 
PRECIPITATION (PCPN) IS ANTICIPATED.

WILL PLOT OUT HIGH TEMPS FROM YESTERDAY...AND CHECK AGAINST 
FORECASTED HIGHS FOR TODAY...TO MAKE SURE THAT WE ARE ALLOWING FOR A
COUPLE OF DEGREES WARMER ACROSS THE BOARD.  AN INTERESTING NOTE IS 
THAT WE WERE CORRECT IN THINKING THAT ALL MOS GUIDANCE WAS LIKELY 
TOO WARM FOR THIS WEEKEND MAX TEMPS.  THE AVERAGE ERROR FROM 
NGM/ETA/MAV MOS FOR YESTERDAY AT 3 MAIN SITES WAS JUST OVER 4 
DEGREES TOO WARM.

WILL CHECK GRIDS AND SEE IF JUST A MINOR ADJUSTMENT OR TWO ARE NEEDED
FOR CURRENT TEMPS/DEWPOINTS/ETC.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
355 AM EDT SUN JUL 24 2005

.SHORT TERM (TODAY THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS 
REVEALS A LARGE AREA OF HIGH PRESSURE CENTERED OVER THE MID ATLANTIC 
STATES...WITH A HUMID AIRMASS REMAINING OVER THE FORECAST AREA. 
DEWPOINTS HAVE LOWERED OVERNIGHT ACROSS NORTHEAST TN AND SOUTHWEST 
VA...BUT THINK THAT THEY WILL SLOWLY RISE AGAIN TONIGHT INTO MONDAY 
WITH SOUTHWEST WINDS EXPECTED TO DEVELOP. A STRONG UPPER-LEVEL HIGH 
OVER THE LOWER MS RIVER VALLEY WILL CONTINUE TO SLOWLY MOVE EAST 
TOWARD THE TN RIVER VALLEY TODAY. THIS UPPER HIGH SHOULD BECOME 
CENTERED OVER THE FORECAST AREA ON MONDAY...WITH THE HOTTEST TEMPS 
EXPECTED THEN. MOS GUIDANCE TEMPS HAVE BEEN CONSISTENTLY TOO HIGH 
WITH THIS UPPER HIGH...AND WILL PLAN TO JUST RAISE TODAYS HIGHS A 
COUPLE OF DEGREES ABOVE YESTERDAYS HIGHS...AND RAISE MONDAYS HIGHS 
A COUPLE OF DEGREES WARMER THAN TODAYS EXPECTED HIGHS. STRONG 
SUBSIDENCE ALOFT COMBINED WITH A DECENT CAPPING INVERSION SHOULD 
HELP TO SUPPRESS ANY POSSIBLE CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY THROUGH MONDAY 
NIGHT. MODELS CONTINUE TO DEVELOP A FEW MESOSCALE CONVECTIVE SYSTEMS 
ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES REGION TODAY AND MONDAY...AND THEN TRACKING 
THEM SOUTHEAST INTO THE MID ATLANTIC STATES. THINK THAT WITH THE 
UPPER HIGH IN THE REGION...IT SHOULD DEFLECT ANY MCS ACTIVITY AWAY 
FROM THE FORECAST AREA THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT.
&&

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY THROUGH SATURDAY)...UPPER HIGH STARTING TO LET 
GO ON TUESDAY...BUT MOST CONVECTION WILL STILL BE SUPPRESSED.  WARM 
LAYER AT ABOUT 800-850 MB THAT IS CAPPING LOWER LAYERS STILL LOOKS 
VERY WARM UNTIL WEDNESDAY AND ESPECIALLY WEDNESDAY NIGHT AS LIFT 
FROM APPROACHING UPPER TROUGH START TO COOL COLUMN.  STILL PLAN ON 
TUESDAY AS VERY WARM WITH WEDNESDAY BEING A TRANSITION DAY TO A 
DEFINITELY COOLER DAY ON THURSDAY.  DECENT CHANCE OF SEVERE STORMS 
WEDNESDAY AND WEDNESDAY NIGHT AS CAP ERODES FROM NORTHWEST OVER 
STEAMY BOUNDARY LAYER AIR.  HARD TO KNOW AT THIS POINT HOW FAR SOUTH 
FRONT WILL SETTLE...RAISED POPS A LITTLE IN NORTHERN AREAS FOR LATER 
IN THE WEEK...JUST NOT CONFIDENT FRONT WILL MAKE IT FAR ENOUGH SOUTH 
TO CLEAR OUT ALL PRECIP.

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY)...MAIN CONCERN CONTINUES TO BE

TEMPS HAVE ALREADY WARMED FROM 1 TO 3 DEGREES ABOVE MAX TEMPS ON 
FRIDAY...ALTHO HEAT INDICES SO FAR ARE JUST INTO THE 90 TO 95 DEGREE 
RANGE OVER OUR FORECAST AREA.  DEWPOINT TEMPS HAVE LOWERED SLIGHTLY 
HELPING TO TAKE THE EDGE OFF OF THE HEAT INDICES...MAINLY OVER 
HIGHER ELEVATIONS AND SWRN VA.  DID NOTICE THAT MOS DEWPOINTS 
GENERALLY WERE TOO LOW INITIALLY ACROSS MOST OF THE FORECAST AREA 
...ESPECIALLY GFS/MAV.   

SOME MODERATE CUMULUS CLOUDS NOTED BUT RAINFREE ON AREA RADARS THIS 
AFTERNOON.  PLAN TO RUN WITH A DRY FORECAST RIGHT INTO MONDAY AT 
THIS POINT.  DONT SEE A SIGNIFICANT THREAT OF ANY MCS ACTIVITY 
REACHING THIS FAR SOUTH ON SUNDAY NIGHT...AND THE ATMOSPHERE LOOKS 
DRY AND TOO WARM ALOFT FOR ANY CONVECTION DURING THE AFTERNOONS AND 
EVENINGS.  

OTHERWISE...ADDED SOME PATCHY VALLEY FOG FOR MAINLY THE SEQUATCHIE 
VALLEY AND NRN VALLEY AREAS LATE TONIGHT...SIMILAR TO WHAT OCCURRED 
THIS MORNING.  MIN TEMPS WERE ADJUSTED CLOSE TO PERSISTENCE...WITH 
MAX TEMPS ALLOWED TO WARM 1 TO 3 DEGREES EACH DAY.  

SPECIAL WEATHER STATEMENT (SPSMRX) FOR THE HEAT WAS TWEAKED AND 
ISSUED ALREADY.


.LONG TERM (MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY)...HOT RIDGE DRIFTS SOUTH 
AND EAST THROUGH THE EARLY PART OF THE FCST PD BUT NOT BEFORE 
CREATING ANOTHER EXCESSIVELY HOT DAY TUE COMPLETE WITH CONTINUED 
SUBSIDENCE AND COMPRESSION. AN UPR TROF DROPS SE INTO THE NERN U.S. 
DRIVING FRONTAL BOUNDARY TWD THE FA ON WED WITH SLOW MOVEMENT INTO 
THE MID SOUTH ON THU. USED 30-40 PERCENT POP FOR THE TWO DAY PERIOD 
AS FRONT BUILDS JUST SOUTH OF TN. FRONT PROGGED TO MEANDER BACK INTO 
THE FA ON SAT AND ADJUSTED POPS INTO A NORTH HALF/SOUTH HALF 
ARRANGEMENT WITH SLGT CHC N AND CHC S CLOSER TO STALLED FRONTAL 
BOUNDARY. GRADUALLY PULLED MAX/MIN TEMPS BACK TOWARD CLIMO AS RIDGE 
REPLACED BY TROUGHING AND SLIGHTLY HIER DEWPOINTS.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1010 AM EDT SAT JUL 23 2005

.DISCUSSION...MORNING UPPER AIR PLOTS SHOW THAT THE UPPER RIDGE IS 
STILL GENERALLY JUST TO OUR WEST...KEEPING THE FORECAST AREA UNDER 
WEAK NW FLOW ALOFT.  THE 12Z OHX SOUNDING IS STARTING TO SHOW THE 
EFFECTS OF THE RIDGING...AS LAYER FROM 850 TO 700 MBS HAS WARMED 
CONSIDERABLY FROM YESTERDAY.  MEANWHILE...FURTHER EAST THE 12Z RNK 
SOUNDING SHOWS LESS WARMING ALOFT AND A WEAKER CAP.  ANOTHER MAJOR 
CHANGE NOTED FROM 12Z SOUNDINGS IS THE BIG REDUCTION IN PRECIPITABLE 
WATER VALUES...WITH OHX DOWN FROM 1.70 INCHES TO 1.17 INCHES...AND 
RNK DOWN FROM 1.81 INCHES TO 0.98 INCHES.  THIS MOISTURE DROP AND 
STRONGER CAPPING INVERSION SHOULD SUPPRESS ANY CONVECTIVE 
DEVELOPMENT THIS AFTERNOON...SO WILL CONTINUE WITH THE DRY FORECAST.

NOTICED THAT MOS HAS BEEN RUNNING A FEW DEGREES TOO WARM ON HIGHS 
EACH DAY...BUT THIS TREND COULD END TODAY GIVEN THE DRYING THAT HAS 
OCCURRED.  HOWEVER...THE MOIST SOIL MUST STILL BE FACTORED IN...AND
SHOULD KEEP HIGHS DOWN A BIT.

DOES NOT APPEAR THAT A MORNING UPDATE IS NEEDED...BUT WILL LOOK OVER 
THE GRIDS FOR ANY POSSIBLE MINOR TWEAKS.

&&

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 230726
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
326 AM EDT SAT JUL 23 2005

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS REVEALS A 
HUMID AIRMASS REMAINING OVER THE FORECAST AREA...WITH YESTERDAYS 
WEAK COLD FRONT EVIDENTLY WASHED-OUT AS IT REMAINS HARD TO FIND 
ACROSS THE REGION. MODELS INDICATE THAT A STRONG UPPER-LEVEL RIDGE 
OF HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE SOUTHERN PLAINS WILL SLOWLY MOVE EAST 
TOWARD THE FORECAST AREA TODAY. THIS WILL CAUSE TEMPS TO RISE TO 
THEIR WARMEST LEVELS SO FAR THIS YEAR. STRONG SUBSIDENCE ALOFT 
COMBINED WITH A CAPPING INVERSION SHOULD HELP TO SUPPRESS ANY 
POSSIBLE CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING. AS FOR 
TEMPS...WILL PLAN TO SLIGHTLY UNDERCUT THE COOLER GFS MOS NUMBERS BY 
A DEGREE TODAY...SINCE THE FAIRLY HIGH SOIL MOISTURE CONTENT ACROSS 
THE FORECAST AREA SHOULD HELP TO LIMIT THE AMOUNT OF WARMING. THESE 
HIGH TEMPS COMBINED WITH HIGH DEWPOINTS SHOULD CREATE AFTERNOON HEAT 
INDICES IN THE 95 TO 100 DEGREE RANGE ACROSS MOST OF THE FORECAST 
AREA.

.LONG TERM (SUNDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...UPPER HIGH CONTINUES THROUGH 
MONDAY THEN STARTS TO FADE OFF TO THE SOUTHEAST.  FOR SUNDAY...BIG 
QUESTION IS THE POSSIBILITY OF MCS REMNANTS FROM GRT LKS HEADING 
SOUTHWARD AFFECTING AREA.  GFS SHOWS THIS...BUT NO OTHER MODELS.  
WILL IGNORE GFS/MAV POPS AND COOLER TEMPS FOR SUNDAY AT THIS TIME 
AND KEEP US UNDER COVER OF RIDGE.  BY MONDAY...HI CENTER SPENDS THE 
DAY AT GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAINS NP...SO ANY MCS ACTIVITY WOULD BE 
DIRECTED WELL AROUND CWA, ETC.  ALSO ON MONDAY SURFACE FLOW LOOKS 
LIKE IT MAY START ALLOWING EVEN HIGHER DEW POINTS TO GET BACK INTO 
THE AREA AGAIN.  HEAT INDEX CRANKS UP TO ABOUT 107 DEGREES AT KCHA 
ON MONDAY.  MINIMUM TEMPS STILL TOO COOL TO CONSIDER HEAT 
ADVISORY...WILL KEEP SPS GOING.  

FOR TUESDAY...UPPER HIGH STARTS TO SLIDE OFF...BUT EASTERN PART OF CWA
WILL LIKELY STILL BE UNDER STRONG INFLUENCE OF IT. BUMPED UP HIGH TEMPS
IN EASTERN TIER OR TWO A LITTLE CLOSER TO MONDAY TEMPS.

&&

AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
257 PM EDT FRI JUL 22 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND SATURDAY)...CURRENT RADAR SHOWS VERY 
LITTLE COVERAGE AT THE MOMENT.  WILL PROBABLY CARRY 20 POPS FOR 
EARLY THIS EVENING...BUT MAY ADJUST BASED ON LATEST RADAR AT THE 
LAST MINUTE.  HEIGHTS RISE AS UPPER RIDGE BUILDS IN THROUGH 
SATURDAY. LOOKS LIKE SUBSIDENCE AND DEEP LAYER DRYING SHOULD KEEP 
TOMORROW DRY.  WILL NOT STRAY FAR FROM MAV TEMPS...BUT WILL CUT A 
COUPLE OF DEGREES OFF CHA HIGH TEMP FOR TOMORROW.  


.LONG TERM...(SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY)...MEDIUM TO LONG RANGE 
MODELS CONSISTENT IN BUILDING UPPER RIDGE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA 
THIS WEEKEND INTO TUESDAY.  AFTER CONSIDERING THE AMOUNT OF DRYING 
AND SUBSIDENCE WARMING...IT SEEMS THAT CONVECTION WILL BE INHIBITED
BOTH SATURDAY AND SUNDAY.  A STRAY SHOWER OR STORM MIGHT TRY TO 
DEVELOP IN THE HIGHER TERRAIN...BUT SHOULD BE SHORT LIVED AND VERY 
ISOLATED SATURDAY EVENING AND ALSO SUNDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING. 
THUS...WE DECIDED TO REMOVE THE SLIGHT CHANCE POPS EVEN FOR THE 
MTNS/HIGHER TERRAIN AREAS FOR THOSE PERIODS.

RIDGE WEAKENS AS UPPER TROUGH DEVELOPS ACROSS THE MID TO UPPER MISS 
VALLEY REGION BY TUESDAY NIGHT.  ASSOCIATED FRONTAL BOUNDARY IS 
PROGGED TO SETTLE JUST INTO NRN PARTS OF THE FORECAST AREA BY 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT...THEN POSSIBLY MOVE AS FAR SOUTH AS SRN TN BORDER 
BY 12Z FRIDAY.  OF COURSE MUCH UNCERTAINTY IN TIMING A FRONTAL 
BOUNDARY IN THE SUMMER...ESPECIALLY SO FAR OUT.  HOWEVER...FOR NOW 
POPS/WX WERE ADJUSTED TO FIT THIS SCENARIO...AND DEWPOINT TEMPS WERE 
ALLOWED TO DECREASE SLIGHTLY FROM WEDS NIGHT INTO FRIDAY.  ALSO... 
RAISED POPS ON TUE AND WED TO BETTER MESH WITH NEIGHBORS AND HPC 
FORECAST.

OTHERWISE...WARMEST TEMPS OF THE SEASON ON TRACK FOR SAT THRU 
TUE...AND WILL UPDATE THE SPS ON THIS SUBJECT.  MIN TEMPS AND 
DEWPOINT TEMPS ARE A BIT TRICKY...ESPECIALLY IF THE MIXING OF DRY 
AIR FROM ALOFT LEADS TO LOWER DEWPOINTS THAN ANTICIPATED.  THIS 
WOULD LEND SOME SUPPORT TO MOS MIN TEMPS AS LOW AS UPPER 50S TO 
LOWER 60S IN NRN AREAS.

FXUS64 KMRX 220752
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
352 AM EDT FRI JUL 22 2005

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS A 
COLD FRONT ACROSS THE MID WEST...WITH A MESOSCALE CONVECTIVE COMPLEX 
(MCS) OVER NORTHERN KY. THIS MCS SHOULD CONTINUE TO MOVE SOUTHEAST 
AND INTO THE FORECAST AREA THIS MORNING...BUT THINK IT SHOULD 
CONTINUE TO WEAKEN AS IT MOVES INTO A MORE STABLE AIRMASS OVER THE 
FORECAST AREA. THE PERSISTENT TSTORM COMPLEX OVER THE NORTHERN 
CUMBERLAND PLATEAU SHOULD ALSO HELP TO STABILIZE THE LOCAL AIRMASS 
AND WEAKEN THE LEADING EDGE OF THIS MCS. WILL PLAN TO RAISE POPS 
INTO THE LIKELY CATEGORY FOR THIS MORNING...AND KEEP A CHANCE FOR 
ADDITIONAL CONVECTION FOR THIS AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING AS THE 
COLD FRONT MOVES INTO THE AREA. HOWEVER...WITH THIS MORNINGS 
CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY...THINK THE LOCAL AIRMASS WILL BE SLOW TO 
DESTABILIZE AGAIN WITH ONLY SCATTERED ACTIVITY EXPECTED IN THE 
AFTERNOON. ALSO...WILL NOT RAISE MAX TEMPS FOR THIS AFTERNOON ABOVE 
YESTERDAYS VALUES...SINCE TEMPS SHOULD BE SLOW TO RISE THIS MORNING 
WITH CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY IN THE AREA.

.LONG TERM (SATURDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...STILL ON TRACK TO HAVE 
UPPER HIGH TO MIGRATE RIGHT ON TOP OF US BY MONDAY.  STILL LEANING 
TOWARD COOL SIDE OF GUIDANCE ON HIGH TEMPS SUN-TUE SINCE SOILS HAVE BEEN
FAIRLY MOIST LATELY. HIGHS ON THURSDAY IN PLAINS WERE GENERALLY
OVERFORECAST BY MAV IN NON-DROUGHT AREAS. FORECASTING HEAT INDEX VALUES
FLIRTING WITH 105 DEGREES IN SOUTHERN SECTIONS...BUT AT LEAST TEMPS WILL
COOL SOMEWHAT AT NIGHT...NOT REALLY THREATENING HEAT ADVISORY CRITERIA.
HOWEVER...WILL CONTINUE WITH SPECIAL WEATHER STATEMENT SINCE THIS IS THE FIRST
HEAT WAVE OF THIS SUMMER.

THINK MODELS ARE OVERPLAYING SOME OF THE DRYING IN THE LOWER LEVELS THIS
WEEKEND AS WELL. WOULD EXPECT A FEW DEGREES SHAVED OFF DEW POINTS...BUT
THINK THAT THE SUNDAY AM LOW OF 60 AT KTRI BY THE MAV IS TOO COOL/DRY.
ORIENTATION OF DRIEST DEW POINTS ON MODELS AS THEY MOVE SOUTH MUST BACK-
DOOR INTO AREA...THINK THOSE DRIEST DEW POINTS MAY STAY ON OTHER SIDE OF
APPS. 

NO CHANGES BEYOND TUESDAY.

&&

305 PM EDT THU JUL 21 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND FRI)...RADAR SHOWS ISOLATED TO SCATTERED 
CONVECTION OVER THE AREA...THINK THIS WILL DIMINISH THIS EVENING AS 
WE LOSE HEATING...BUT GIVEN MOIST AIRMASS AND THE FACT THAT THERE

THROUGH OVERNIGHT PERIOD.  TOMORROW...TAIL END OF UPPER TROUGH 
ASSOCIATED WITH COMPLEX OVER GREAT LAKES REGION TODAY MAY AFFECT OUR 
AREA...ESPECIALLY THE NORTH.  NAM MOST BULLISH WITH THIS FEATURE.  
WILL NOT GO AS FAR AS THE NAM...BUT WILL GO WITH 40 TO 50 POPS 
NORTH...AND 30 TO 40 SOUTH.  WILL GENERALLY GO CLOSE TO MAV TEMPS 
TONIGHT...BUT WILL UNDERCUT A DEGREE OR TWO NORTH AND CENTRAL 
TOMORROW WITH POSSIBILITY OF MORE CLOUDS.   

.LONG TERM...(FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY)...FORECAST AREA REMAINS 
IN WEAK NW FLOW ALOFT INITIALLY UNTIL THE UPPER RIDGE BUILDS EAST 
FROM THE PLAINS STATES.  THUS...COVERAGE OF CONVECTIVE PCPN IS 
UNCERTAIN FOR FRIDAY NIGHT.  MODELS HINT AT PERHAPS AN MCS AFFECTING 
THE FORECAST AREA DURING THE DAY FRIDAY...WITH POPS DIMINISHING FROM 
THE NW FRIDAY EVENING.  KEPT POP/WX GRIDS DRAWN FOR THIS SCENARIO...
BUT THERE MIGHT JUST BE A GENERAL DECREASE IN SHOWERS/STORMS WITH 
LOSS OF HEATING.  

UPPER RIDGE BUILDS IN OVER THE WEEKEND INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK...WHICH 
WILL SERVE TO LIMIT CONVECTION.  TEMPS ALSO ON THE RISE BUT PROBABLY 
NO HIGHER THAN MID TO UPPER 90S FOR MAX TEMPS.  UPDATED THE HWO 
PRODUCT TO INCLUDE A MENTION OF HOT TEMPS AND HEAT INDICES...AND 
WILL LIKELY ISSUE AN SPS WITH SAME INFORMATION WITH THE AFTERNOON
PACKAGE.

BY MID NEXT WEEK...DGEX/GFS/ECMWF AND ENSEMBLES INDICATE THE RIDGE 
BREAKS DOWN.  UPPER LEVEL TROUGH DEVELOPS ACROSS UPPER MIDWEST AND 
GREAT LAKES...WITH ASSOCIATED WEAK COLD FRONT TO DROP INTO SRN OHIO 
VALLEY BY 12Z THURSDAY.  THUS...INCREASED RAIN CHANCES BY WEDS NIGHT 
INTO THURSDAY MUCH IN LINE WITH LATEST HPC GUIDANCE.  DID UNDERCUT 
GUIDANCE HIGHS ON THURSDAY DUE TO ANTICIPATED CLOUDS AND PCPN.

000 
FXUS64 KMRX 201959
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
358 PM EDT WED JUL 20 2005

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY)...REGIME OF CONVECTION 
FIRING ON PLATEAU AND MOVING IN MID LEVEL FLOW SEEMS TO BE 
CONTINUING THIS AFTERNOON.  WEAK SHEAR AXIS THAT SEEMED TO 
SUPPLEMENT THIS DEVELOPMENT FOR THE PAST TWO DAYS SEEMS TO HAVE 
FADED TODAY.  THINKING THERE WILL BE VERY LITTLE OVERNIGHT 
PRECIP...SO HAVE ONLY MINIMAL POPS AFTER SUNSET...THEN REFIRING IN 
HIGHER TERRAIN ON THURSDAY.  ALSO ON THURSDAY...WEAK UPPER LEVEL 
SHORTWAVE TROUGH SHOULD BE SAGGING INTO THE NORTHERN PARTS OF THE 
AREA.  WILL GO WITH HIGHER POPS OVER NORTHWEST SECTIONS.  UPPER FLOW 
SHOULD START OUT WEAK...BUT PICK UP A LITTLE AS TROUGH MOVES IN. 

ADJUSTED DEW POINT FIELDS TO BRING MORE IN LINE WITH OBSERVED 
VALUES.  CURRENT LOW TEMP TONIGHT LOOKS GOOD...TWEAKED HIGH TEMP FOR 
TOMORROW JUST 1-2 DEGREES AT MOST.


.LONG TERM...(THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...FOR THURSDAY NIGHT 
INTO FRIDAY NIGHT...THE NW FLOW ALOFT COULD EASILY SEND MCS ACTIVITY 
OUR WAY.  HOWEVER...SHORT RANGE MODELS DONT HINT AT ANY MCS 
REACHING OUR FORECAST AREA...SO THIS JUST REMAINS A POSSIBILITY AT 
THIS TIME.  THUS...GIVEN GOOD MOISTURE SUPPLY AND MODERATE OR BETTER 
INSTABILITY...TRIED TO STAY CLOSE TO MOS BLEND FOR AT LEAST DIURNAL 
CONVECTION.  POPS/WX/SKY WERE ALL ADJUSTED TO BETTER MESH WITH 
NEIGHBORS GRIDS/FORECAST.  KEPT MAX TEMPS JUST BELOW THE WARMEST MOS 
LIKE PREVIOUS GRIDS...WITH PERSISTENCE GOOD FOR MINS.  

SATURDAY INTO MONDAY...THIS SHOULD BE THE DRIEST PERIOD OF THE 
FORECAST AS UPPER RIDGE BUILDS EASTWARD FROM THE CENTRAL PLAINS AND 
SWRN STATES...SHIFTING THE WESTERLIES AND ANY MCS TRACK FURTHER 
NORTH OF THE REGION.  LINGERING MOISTURE (SOIL AND RESIDUAL) COULD 
INHIBIT HOW HIGH MAX TEMPS GET...SO KEPT MAX TEMPS JUST BELOW HPC 
AND GFS MOS FOR SATURDAY AND SUNDAY.  FINAL EDITS THESE PERIODS WERE 
MADE TO ADD A SLIGHT CHANCE OF TSRA FOR SATURDAY AFTERNOON...ACROSS
THE FORECAST AREA.  

TUESDAY AND WEDNESDAY...ENSEMBLE MEANS FROM GFS AND ECMWF SUPPORT 
LESS UPPER LEVEL TROUGHING AND FRONTAL PUSH SOUTH THAN OPERATIONAL 
GFS MODEL INDICATES.  THUS...STAYED BELOW GFS MOS AND HPC GUIDANCE 
POPS FOR THESE DAYS.  ALSO RAISED GFS DEWPOINTS SLIGHTLY WITH LESS 
PUSH OF ANY DRIER AIR EXPECTED.

DEPENDING ON ITS EVOLUTION. RIDGING AND LAYER DRYING BUILDS IN LATER 
ON FRI. HEIGHT RISES FOR THE WEEKEND HAVE BACKED OFF A NOTCH.

EXPECTED.
